Re File 971-304-11 A.U. May 26th, 1948.

As requested in your above letter I recently visited Round Lake School and discussed with the Principal the matter of overcoming the fire hazards mentioned in the Inspector's report. Enclosed herewith is a requisition for the material required, the Principal is willing to have the work done by his staff.

As regards the furnace room this would require 1272 sq.ft. of Flexboard to make it fire proof. We have included this on our requisition.

With reference to the Inspector's recommendations I beg to report as follows:

1. Two doors with double acting hinges are included in our requisition.
2. Pipes and collars for kitchen range will be purchased by the Principal.
3. Kitchen stove will be moved out 18" from wall and asbestos Flexboard has been requested in our requisition.
4. All loose electric ends have already been taped.
5. Material for a chimney in the men's sleeping quarters is included in our requisition.
6. The defective fire extinguishers have been taken to Whitewood for repairs.

W.J. Kerley,
Superintendent.
PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN

Office of the Fire Commissioner

May 21, 1948.

Dear Sir:

On May 7, 1948, I visited Round Lake Indian Residential School for the purpose of making a fire inspection of the building. Upon arrival I contacted Mr. J.H. Card, Engineer, who accompanied me through the school.

It was immediately noticed that the building was very old and in poor state of repair, especially in the basement section of the building. Because of the building's age and type of construction, if a fire should break out in any section of the premises, it would spread very rapidly and would be very difficult to control. The furnace room is in a very poor state of repair with exposed joists above the heating plant, improper fuel storage, no enclosures to shut off the furnace room from the rest of the building, and a gasoline engine driving an electric plant, together with storage batteries within a few feet of the furnace. It would be very difficult to improve this condition unless a complete renovation job was carried out and I do not believe the rest of the building warrants this expense.

In view of the above-mentioned hazards, it would be in the interest of good fire prevention practices to give immediate consideration to improving the conditions which exist in this building.

Listed hereunder are recommendations which could be applied, with very little cost and would improve conditions considerably:

1. Doors would be placed on landings of main staircase on both 2nd and 3rd floors. These doors would prevent the spread of fire and smoke from floor to floor which, of course, would give students more time, in the event of a fire, to reach the fire escape. It appears as though there had been doors on these landings at some earlier date and had since been removed.

2. Chimney inlet for smoke pipes of kitchen range requires repairs.

3. Kitchen stove moved out from wall to a distance of 16" and a wall protected from the heat of the stove by asbestos board and an air space.
4. All loose electric wire ends to be properly taped.

5. The heater in the men's sleeping quarters to be serviced by an approved chimney. At the present time the smoke pipes from the heater pass through the roof of the building.

6. Several new extinguishers have been purchased in the past year and a large percentage of same were found to be plugged. These extinguishers should either be returned to the manufacturers or repaired and left in working condition.

Trusting you will give these recommendations your personal and immediate attention and advise this office accordingly when recommendations have been complied with as we would appreciate your fullest cooperation in this regard. I am

Very truly yours,

Sgd. R.A.W. Switzer,
Fire Inspector.

Mr. J. B. Ostrander,
Department of Indian Affairs,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

RAW/RB

I am enclosing copy of Mr. Kerley's letter and requisitions for materials required to make this building comply with provincial fire regulations. Mr. Kerley states that the Principal is willing to have the labour performed by the staff of the school. Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Attention Mr. Heey,

Dear Sir:

Early this summer our Jacket Heater ceased to function because of the water pipes gradually being choked by the mineral salts adhering to the inside of the water pipes.

About that time the Indian Agent, Mr. Kerley was on a tour of inspection and realizing that we could not get along without the heater ordered one shipped to us.

Yesterday Mr. Kerley was here and advised me that the cost of heater had not been paid to Crane Limited of Regina.

Enclosed are copies of the invoice with the request that this matter be given your consideration.

As mentioned several years ago this is not caused by misuse or overloading the heater but by the minerals and salts in the water which we have to use.

Your attention would be greatly appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School,
Whitecourt, Sask.

In reply to your letter # I. A. 1556-11 of the 26th ultimo, the following are the facts requested:

1. There is a Pump House 8' x 8' over a "wet well" at the lake shore, this well is 4' square and 11' deep with 5' of water at present. The suction line of 1" pipe is connected to the water pump in the boiler room. The water is pumped into a cistern 9' in diameter, 9' deep in the boiler room by a F. M. air cooled 2½ H.P. engine connected to a pump jack to an old pump said to be a F. M. (name could not be determined). This outfit cannot pump the wet well dry.

2. The difference in the level of the water in the wet well to the highest point where the suction pipe enters the boiler room is about 40 feet. It appears that this pipe could have been put in lower so it comes in 6 feet over the top of the pump. If the pump is put in the Pump House at the lake shore, an oil stove would be the best method to heat it, as being so small there would be no room for fuel. The present pump there takes 3 to 4 hours to pump the cistern full.

3. The size of the suction pipe is 1½" and is 378 feet from one pump to the other.

4. The electric supply is a 32 Volt D.C. unit, driven by a F. M. Z Type Self Oiling 6-7 H.P. gasoline engine. The same engine is used to drive the pump by another pulley.

5. The existing pump is a F. M. Self Oiling Typhoon Pump, Pressure 100 lb., Speed 215 R.P.M., 2500 G.P.H.

6. The F. M. 1000 G.P.H. Self Oiling Typhoon Pump #6659 has been sent back to Winnipeg.

The old pump is worn out beyond repair, it leaked so badly that it caused the shorting of the Generator which is situated close by. I might add that the whole set-up is very bad and in very poor shape. The measurements given were supplied by Mr. Leishman of the Round Lake School Staff. Any assistance that you can provide will be greatly appreciated.

W. J. D. Kerley,
Superintendent.

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School, Whitewood, Sask.

Further to our memorandum of January 31st, you are advised that we are in receipt of information from Indian Superintendent Kerley with regard to the arrangement of the water supply system at the above.

We have analyzed the data presented in Mr. Kerley's letter of February 3rd, and it may be summarized as follows.

There is a "wet well" located at the Lake, a distance of approximately 378 feet from a concrete reservoir in the boiler room of the school building. An old pump powered by a 25 H.P. gasoline engine pumps water from the "wet well" into the reservoir in the boiler room. From the reservoir in the boiler room the water is pumped into a pressure tank by another pump which is driven by a pulley and belt from the diesel engine connected to the electric generator set. Mr. Kerley states that this pump is worn out and leaks so badly that further repairs are impossible.

A new Fairbanks-Morse 1000 g.p.h. pump was recently purchased and installed to replace the old unit referred to. This new pump failed to give satisfactory service and has been returned to the Winnipeg Branch of the Fairbanks-Morse Company. A request from Indian Superintendent Kerley for authority to purchase a 6000 g.p.h. pump was then received by the Indian Affairs Branch, at which time they sought an opinion from this Division.

Following the above summary, it is our opinion that the 1000 g.p.h. pump should serve the purpose if properly installed. It is therefore recommended that the Fairbanks-Morse Company be requested to supply a self-priming Typhoon pump suitable for belted service having a capacity to deliver 1000 g.p.h. against 100 lbs. per square inch pressure when connected by suitable pulley and belt to the existing Fairbanks-Morse Type Z self-priming 6-7 H.P., gasoline engine.

It is also recommended that the Fairbanks-Morse representatives in Winnipeg be requested to direct the installation of this pump and put it into satisfactory service.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Further to your memorandum under date of Feb. 17th which is enclosed.

The statement in first paragraph sets out the condition and manner of getting our necessary supply of water for all purposes except for drinking and cooking. This entails going across the lake in the winter to a spring. The greater part of the year we haul our water from a spring about 4 miles distant on No. 9 highway since it is not possible to reach the first mentioned spring by going overland.

It was in December while I was in Hospital with an attack of Pneumonia that the old pressure pump gave out. Our man at the school phoned me at the hospital saying that the only pump he found available was one of 1000 G.P.H. I advised accepting it. Certainly, if we have to expend our moneys for Jacket Heaters, Pressure Pumps, and other such purchases it will not be possible to keep within our budget.

We would request that the purchase of this new pressure pump be taken by the Department of Mines and Resources - Indian Affairs Branch.

Yours respectfully,

Memorandum
Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School, Whitewood, Sask.

Ottawa, February 17 1949.

Further to our memorandum of January 31st, you are advised that we are in receipt of information from Indian Superintendent Kerley with regard to the arrangement of the water supply system at the above.

We have analyzed the data presented in Mr Kerley's letter of February 3rd, and it may be summarized as follows.

There is a "wet well" located at the Lake, a distance of approximately 378 feet from a concrete reservoir in the boiler room of the school building. An old pump powered by a 2½ H.P. gasoline engine pumps water from the "wet well" to the reservoir in the boiler room. From the reservoir in the boiler room the water is pumped into a pressure tank by another pump which is driven by a pulley and belt from the diesel engine connected to the electric generator set. Mr Kerley states that this pump is worn out and leaks so badly that further repairs are impossible.

A new Fairbanks-Morse 1000 g.p.h. pump was recently purchased and installed to replace the old unit referred to. This new pump failed to give satisfactory service and has been returned to the Winnipeg Branch of the Fairbanks-Morse Company. A request from Indian Superintendent Kerley for authority to purchase a 2500 g.p.h. pump was then received by the Indian Affairs Branch, at which time they sought an opinion from this Division.

Following the above summary, it is our opinion that the 1000 g.p.h. pump should serve the purpose if properly installed. It is therefore recommended that the Fairbanks-Morse Company be requested to supply a self oiling Typhoon pump suitable for belted service having a capacity to deliver 1000 g.p.h. against 100 lbs. per square inch pressure when connected by suitable pulley and belt to the existing Fairbanks-Morse Type Z self oiling 6-7 H.P. gasoline.

It is also recommended that the Fairbanks-Morse representatives in Winnipeg be requested to direct the installation of this pump and put it into satisfactory service.

With reference to Department letter of the 4th instant, 661-1 (E) regarding continuation of the Round Lake Residential School for another year or two, I visited the school this week, accompanied by Indian Superintendent Kerley, to enquire into the matter of the erection of the barn.

Mr. Gard, the Principal is away on holidays and Mr. Leichman, the Farming Instructor, was in charge, therefore it was necessary to discuss the matter of stable accommodation for the cattle and horses with Mr. Leichman.

I found that there are eighteen Holstein cows being milked at the present time and four more are to calve shortly which would mean twenty or more milking cows when the school opens the last of September. In addition to this there are 30 head of other cattle made up of young heifers and young steers. They are all Holstein breeding. It was their intention to butcher the steers for winter meat at the school and to keep the heifers for replacement of aged milk cows.

It is my opinion that there has always been too large a herd of cattle at the Round Lake School. If they intend to milk cows to have the milk for the use of the pupils, ten cows would be enough to keep with the present pupilage. Owing to the fact that the cost of erecting stable accommodation for the large number of cattle at the school, (and the fact that the main building is really not fit for occupancy at all,) I do not recommend erection of a cattle barn and I would recommend disposing of all of the cattle before the winter sets in and the purchase of powdered milk for food purposes.

However, some stabling accommodation is necessary as it is necessary to keep two teams of horses at the school and occasionally in the winter the Indian Superintendent or the doctor drives to the school with horses and it is necessary to have a double stall for that purpose. In other words I would recommend the erection of a horse barn with three double stalls and a harness and feed room at one end. Enclosed is an estimate of the material necessary for such a building. The estimate was prepared by the Security Lumber Company of Broadview, Saskatchewan on a rough plan which I prepared, the barn being 16 feet wide and 36 feet long with no loft.

Continued on Page 2.
The bill of material amounts to $1009.82, f.o.b. Broadview in addition to which there will freighting and gravel which will probably add a further $150.00. I would recommend that an order be placed at once for the material in accordance with the estimate and requisition enclosed. I endeavored to contact one William Pitcher of Stoughton, Saskatchewan who has done some carpentry work for the Department in the past, as I believe he would take on the work of erecting the building on an hourly basis on a satisfactory manner. However, he was absent and Mr. Kerley will contact him as soon as possible advising me of the possibility of employing him. Assuming that the labour performed in this manner will not exceed 50% of the amount of the bill of material, the barn will cost something under $2,000, and I would recommend that an amount of $2000 be made available for the purpose at the earliest possible date in order that it may be completed before cold weather sets in.

If the school is to continue a complete new lighting plant is needed and it should be 110 volts. The previous plant was 32 volts and there is so little electrical equipment being used from this plant, that a change to a 110 volt will not result in any expense or changing the electrical equipment. If the Department decides to re-open the school for the new term, a lighting plant should be ordered at once.

I investigated the possibility of transferring some of the Government equipment from the File Hills Residential School to the Round Lake Residential School and I communicated to the Department in this connection yesterday asking authority to transfer the following items: 1 H.P. Fairbanks horse engine, 2 oven kitchen range (the one at the Round Lake School is worn our and in my opinion not worth repairing) one small washing machine and one drier.

The heating boiler at the Round Lake School was recently inspected by the Boiler Inspector and he reports it is satisfactory.

In any case I certainly do not think that the Round Lake Residential School should re-open unless a new Principal is appointed as I do not consider Reverend Mr. Card is fitted for the position.

Please instruct me further in this connection at the earliest possible date.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

With reference to the situation at the Round Lake Residential School, and the condition of the health of Reverend J.A. Card, the Principal, I have to report that Mrs. Loveys visited the Round Lake School with me on the 2nd instant. When at the school we found that Reverend Mr. Card was in hospital at Saskatoon under observation as a result of his disturbed mental condition. Mrs. Loveys may receive a telephone message from his son Walter, who is temporarily in charge of the work at the Round Lake Residential School, to the effect that he has been informed by telephone from Saskatoon that Mr. Card's illness has been diagnosed as "hardening of the arteries", with the result that there seems a possibility that he might be in a position to return to his duties at no far distant date. In the meantime I understood from Mrs. Loveys that she is endeavouring to find someone to act temporarily as Principal at the school until Reverend Mr. Card is fit to return to his duties.

Mrs. Loveys is quite determined to continue to have a number of milch cows kept at the Round Lake School, notwithstanding the fact that I have tried to convince her that it would be much less difficult from the point of view of the Department to not build a cow barn at the present time and for the school to purchase the necessary milk for the children. She emphasized the fact that the school was getting a certain amount of profit out of the surplus milk which was being produced by the milch cows, and that this extra profit was necessary for the operation of the school. Of course, in my opinion, it is for the Department to decide whether or not to make this concession in order to improve the financial conditions at the school, at the expense of the taxpayer, by building a barn large enough to house at least 12 head of cows and a bull, in addition to the horse barn which I recommended some time ago as necessary.

Mrs. Loveys suggested that a barn be built for the cows without a loft. Of course this can be done at considerably less cost than would be the cost of a hip-roofed barn with a loft. The milch cows at the school are of Holstein breeding, and if the feed is not kept in the building, and has to be taken into the building twice a day in the cold weather, it would be difficult to keep the cows warm enough that their milk supply would not be considerably reduced. Holstein cows in full milk do not do well if they are not kept warm in the winter.

I shall await the decision of the Department before taking any action to endeavour to find out what would be the cost of a suitable barn for 12 milch cows, and a bull but with a loft, and if we are to build a barn for the cows, the same barn should serve for the horses, and should be made large enough accordingly. I would estimate the cost to be in the neighbourhood of $10,000.00 at least. This might be reduced to $6,000.00 if the barn is built to house 12 cows, a bull, 6 horses, and room for some calves and feed, but without a loft.

I shall appreciate being advised at a very early date as to the decision of the Department in this connection.

With reference to telephone conversation with Colonel Neary on the 27th ultimo a plan of a suitable barn for the Round Lake Indian Residential School was prepared, and quotations given thereon by Harvey Lunan Construction Company, of Regina, after which the writer made an effort to secure quotations on the same building from contractors in Broadview, Messrs. Webb and Melanson, and Mr. W. Wellbelove. Both of these contracting firms declined to submit a tender on the building, as they both stated they had more work ahead of them than they would be able to perform before winter. After making several other enquiries as to contractors who might probably be interested, Mr. William L. Pilchak, of Stockholm, Saskatchewan, was contacted, and a quotation received from him.

Written quotations from the two contractors are enclosed herewith. It will be noted that the quotation of Harvey Lunan Construction Company is $8,500.00 without a loft, and $10,100.00 with a loft, while the quotations given by Mr. William L. Pilchak are $8,000.00 without the loft, and $10,000.00 with the loft. I am enclosing herewith a rough plan of the proposed building with a gable roof, on which the quotations are $8,000.00 and $8,500.00 respectively. Also enclosed is a photostatic copy of a loft and hip-roof on which, if added to the plan shown, the contractors have tendered $10,000.00 and $10,100.00 respectively.

It is very difficult without blue prints and specifications to get tenders quickly on a building of this kind, as very few hip-roof barns, or barns of any kind, are being erected by contractors in late years. However, the plan shown meets with the requirements of the barn necessary at the Round Lake School, and should be erected at the very earliest possible date. I would therefore recommend approval of the plan, and that the contract be awarded to Mr. William L. Pilchak, of Stockholm, Saskatchewan, who will perform the work in accordance with the plan, in either the gable roof type or hip-roof type, with loft.

While I have been rather anxious to have this barn constructed with a loft, and have so requested, I have concluded that the plan shown without a loft will prove quite satisfactory for a few years, as the barn will be warm and, although it will cool at times, when hay or other feed is being taken in or out in the winter time, it will soon become warm again, and I do not think the milch cows will suffer a great deal in the colder weather. Therefore, having given careful consideration to the whole matter, and particularly the urgent need to have a barn completed as quickly as possible, I now recommend that the barn be built without a loft.
a loft by Mr. William L. Pilchak, of Stockholm, Saskatchewan, at the price of $8,000.00; he to supply all material and perform all labour, at the earliest possible date.

May this matter be considered urgent, please, and the necessary authority given me to proceed, at once. There will be some delay in securing all of the material, and I am sure the barn cannot be completed in less than two months from the date of commencement, as Mr. Pilchak will not be able to engage a very large crew of men because of the fact that we are in the midst of harvest.

SPECIFICATIONS ON BARN PROPOSED FOR ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

The Barn to be erected on concrete footings 3 ft. below ground level, the floor to be laid on 2 x 6 stringers firmly at rest in compacted ground, and shall be on 2'6" material laid flat.

Horse stall floor to be of 2 x 4 on edge. Roof to be of 2 x 8 rafters, fitted and roofed with asphalt shingles, insulation to be composed of shavings and lime on ceiling and 2" rock wool in walls.

Exterior walls to be of 2 x 8 studdings at 16" centres, sheeted on interior, with 1" sheeting, and on exterior with 1" sheeting and on exterior with Sisal Kraft paper with siding similar to cove siding. Stanchions shall be of 2 x 4 and posts of 4 x 4.

Contractors to supply all hardware such as locks, hasps, hinges, etc. Wiring to be installed, giving one outlet every 150 sq. ft. with 4 conveniently located plugs, one outside light over entrance door.

Windows to be supplied with storm sash. Trough to drain to exterior ground only.

The feed room is to be metal lined with 26 gauge galvanized iron on 1" or similar material.

Drop-siding to be of fir and all material fir except spruce sheeting.

ROOF

If gable roof, no special specifications other than above. If hip-roof, specifications of rafters and bracing to be in accordance with attached photostatic copy. If hip-roof, and loft is added, the length of the studdings shall be 12' with the floor joist at 8', suitably supported and braced.

The completed job to be in accordance with prescribed practice in every particular, and subject to examination and approval of an official of the Indian Affairs Branch and the Principal of the Round Lake Indian Residential School, at any time.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 26th ultimo, File 661-5 (E2), with which was enclosed memorandum from the Lands and Development Services re the water supply at the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

When visiting the school yesterday I enquired into this and, incidentally, asked the Principal, Reverend J.A. Card, why the test was taken, and at whose request. He informed me that he knew nothing about a test having been taken, or anyone requesting it.

The Department would naturally assume that the water referred to in the test was that being used for drinking and cooking at the school, which is not a fact. The bacteriological report reads: "Sample of drinking water from a cold water tap on first floor of school". There is no water being taken from the taps at the school for drinking purposes other than from tanks especially placed at the school for drinking purposes, and the water in these tanks is obtained from a very fine lively spring some distance from the school. It is hauled regularly to the school for drinking purposes in a clean receptacle. The water from the taps in the bathrooms and other places about the school is used for washing purposes only, and comes from a seepage well near Round Lake. It has been known for years that this water is not fit for drinking or culinary purposes, and it has never been used as such unless deliberately by some member of the staff of the school who should know better.

I do not see that any action should be taken in connection with this memorandum other than I have already taken to ascertain that the staff and the children of the school fully understand that they must drink no water with the exception of

that water which.........
that water which is placed in the proper receptacle for drinking purposes and which is certainly not contaminated water.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The buildings at the Round Lake Indian Residential School are badly in need of exterior painting and there is an item in the current year's Estimates of $3,250.00 for labour and material for this purpose.

I am submitting the matter to the Department for consideration, and it will be noted that the amount is not sub-divided as between material and labour. I have no doubt that if the Department decides to proceed with painting these buildings the necessary paint could be purchased by the Purchasing Agent, and a painter engaged to perform the labour at somewhat less than the amount quoted. If the school year ending June 30th, 1950, will be the end of the operation of the Round Lake Residential School, then I do not recommend the expenditure. With reference to Department letter of the 10th instant, File 661-5 (El), returning Progress Report #2, in connection with the erection of the barn at the Round Lake Indian Residential School, my last visit to the school was on November 4th, and I have been away in the northern part of the province ever since. However, on November 4th I found the barn almost completed, but Mr. Pilchak was short on windows, which the lumber company at Stockholm had been promising to deliver to him for two or three weeks, and, of course, the building cannot be said to be completed until the windows are received and installed.

As stated, I have been away from the office for some time, and must remain here for two or three days to attend to urgent correspondence, therefore I shall not be able to visit the Round Lake School until toward the end of this week, and I am not prepared to make a statement that the work is completed and satisfactory until I have made another visit.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

On Monday I visited the Round Lake Mission and had an interesting talk to the children and a fair visit with the staff there. Mr. Card seems to be in just fair health. He does not seem to be able to stand very much extra effort. His talking with the Indian Agent seems to be a very sore spot. He has not received very much cooperation or assistance from Mr. Curley. The lighting equipment is in very poor repair. They have made several attempts to put it in shape and each time they will have light for a day or two then unannounced darkness. This is not very satisfactory for this type of residence. The carrying of coal-oil lamps and the hanging of metal lamps is a dangerous experiment amongst these youngsters.

There is also a need for some mode of transportation here. It would seem that it would be very helpful if a station wagon of some description might be made available for the transport of the staff and children when necessary from the Mission to town and back again. This station wagon might be put to very good work for the church during the summer months. Maybe we could approach the W.M.S. to do something in this regard. There seems to be a very good spirit prevailing amongst the staff and in the school as a whole.

I am enclosing herewith a Progress Report, which is final, as the barn at the Round Lake Residential School has been completed by the Contractor, Mr. William Pilchak, as per Contract. I might say that Mr. Pilchak has left nothing that could be desired in the way of materials or workmanship in this building.

Mr. Pilchak has received $5,400.00 less $300.00 or his 10% deposit, which was not sent forward on account of the urgency at the time of letting the Contract, and as I stated in my letter of October 31st, I thought the $300.00 security should be waived. 21 head of cattle suffocate

STOCKHOLM, Sask., March 16 (Special to The Canadian Press) — Twenty-one Holstein cattle valued at $4,000, including a fine bull, were killed by suffocation in a fire Wednesday at the Round Lake Indian residential school, 10 miles south of here.

Fire fighters saved the new $10,000 barn from destruction by organizing an insect brigade and by closing the doors after extinguishing several loads of livestock, but failing on a burning tractor which caused the fire.

Barn Damage $500

Damage to the barn was estimated at $500.

Fourteen of the fine herd lost were cows, which supplied the milk within the school.

An overheated tractor which a boy had driven into the barn for the night caused the fire about 4:45 p.m. by igniting a gasoline leak.

John Swanson, who was cutting ice on the lake, used his tractor to pull the burning machine from the barn. His quick action undoubtedly saved the building by reducing the intensity of the blaze.

Led To Safety

Four boys and five sick head of cattle, including several calves, were led to safety before the doors were opened among the flames.

Fire extinguishers and barrels of water hauled to the scene on a truck helped bring the flames under control.

The fire burned through the double wall to the loft in two or three places.

Cattle stabled near the tractor were killed by flames, others by suffocation.

An Old Machine

The old tractor, which is an old machine, was kept in the barn at night for easier starting in the morning when grinding grain, crushing feed and sawing wood.

Round Lake mission, operated by the Roman Catholic Church, is the Indian affairs branch for a new tract of land which would not have to be paid in taxes.

None of the mission staff was on hand when the boy driver brought the machine.

Fire A Year Ago

The new barn, built last fall, replaced one which burned down a year ago with a loss of more than $1,000.

The mission has about 30 Indian pupils, who joined the staff and several other white children.

Located in the Qu'Appelle valley between Stockholm and Wadena, the school is about 140 miles northeast of Regina.
Fuel truck overturns and burns

DAFOE, Sask. (Special) — A truck carrying diesel fuel overturned and burned four miles east of here early last No. 6 Wednesday at 3 p.m. The driver was uninjured. The victim, Clarke, was killed by fire, Moose Jaw.

Escaped through window

It was Tuesday night that the driver had escaped to avoid an incoming car, and had continued driving his vehicle from the burning vehicle by smashing a window.

The vehicle was a three-ton truck with a small tank at the rear. Truck loaded with diesel fuel. Mr. Clarke opened the truck, which was insured, and was operated by the MacCon company of Moose Jaw.

M. Rudnitsky funeral held

PRESCOTT, Sask. (Special) — Funeral services for Mira Rudnitsky, 45, who was crushed to death by a train on Saturday, were conducted Tuesday at the Ukrainian Catholic Church in Prescott. Burial was made in the Ukrainian Catholic cemetery.

Mrs. Rudnitsky was born in Buchanan district. He married Mrs. J. Shumate of Buchanan there in 1928. They lived in Buchanan until 1948, when they moved to Prescottville.

Surviving are a wife, three daughters, Evelyn, Grace, and Mary; a son, Newton, all of Prescottville; two sisters, Mrs. R. Rudnitsky, Prescottville, and Mrs. J. Statnik, Buchanan; two brothers, Bill and Tom, both of Buchanan.

The following is an army message sent to the Department yesterday regarding a fire at the Round Lake School, which resulted in the loss of fourteen cows and estimated damage of $500.00 to the barn:

"MR BLANCHE CROOKED LAKE AGENCY CLERK ADVISED ME BY PHONE OF FIRE IN BARN LAST PM. AT ROUND LAKE SCHOOL STOP REPORTS KEEPING TRACTOR IN BARN AND BACKFIRE STARTED BLAZE STOP INTERIOR OF BARN SCORCHED BUT DAMAGE TO BUILDING OF NO ACCOUNT LOSS EIGHT TO TEN COWS STOP KERLEY AT WHITE BEAR HE WILL INVESTIGATE AND REPORT FULLY IN A FEW DAYS."

Enclosed is a cutting from the Leader Post of March 16th, 1950, with reference to this fire. I have not had Mr. Kerley's report which might furnish somewhat different information from that given in the Leader Post news report. However, I believe that the Department should officially take note and protest one paragraph of this newspaper report. The source of information must have been Reverend J.A. Card, the Principal of the school. The public, who have to pay for our mistakes, are given the impression that Indian Affairs Branch was responsible for supplying a new tractor to the school and that, failing to do so, has been the cause of the fire. Mr. Card asked if the Department would supply a new tractor for his school, and he was informed that the purchase of a new tractor was not the responsibility of Indian Affairs Branch, that such replacements are regular expenses of an Indian Residential School, for which the school is being paid a per capita grant.

With regard to driving an overheated tractor into the barn, I do not need to point out to the Department that this was highly improper and unsafe. If a school boy took it upon himself to drive the tractor into the barn to keep it warm through the night, I have no doubt that it had been a common practice. Also if a school boy was operating the tractor for crushing feed or sawing wood without supervision of an adult member of the school staff, that, also, was definitely wrong.

There is no doubt that a request will be coming from Reverend Mr. Card for the Department to pay the cost of repairing the barn. Unless Mr. Serley's report indicates that the newspaper report is very inaccurate, I do not think that the public should bear the expense of repairing the barn which was built, at the expense of the public, only four months ago.

I wonder if the church authorities will still be quite satisfied with the present management at the school, now that they have lost about £4,000 worth of their cattle through what looks like mismanagement and neglect.

I investigated the fire which occurred in the stable at the Round Lake Residential School on March 15th and submit the following report.

The fire occurred at 4 P.M. The tractor had been sawing wood and the farm manager, Mr. Myles Hoggarth, was taking a truck load of wood to the school. The tractor was driven by Ronald George, a pupil aged 14. He drove the tractor into the barn and shut off the fuel and walked to the other end of the barn; he heard it sputter and then saw a flash and immediately the straw near the tractor burst into flames. The boy ran to the school and got the farm manager who was in the kitchen, and with additional help they put out the fire with extinguishers and water. To prevent draft the doors were kept closed; this made it difficult for the firefighters to gain inside for any length of time. Mr. John Swanson who was cutting ice on Round Lake came with his tractor and pulled the burning tractor from the barn. When the fire was extinguished it was found the cattle had suffocated.

Thirteen cows, one bull, two heifers and four calves died. One front tire of the tractor was burned and both rear tires damaged, the magneto was also burned. The damage to the building consisted of practically all the electric wiring, the west end of the building, ceiling and stalls badly scorched, fifty-seven panes of glass 10" X 12" were cracked or broken.

It is probable that a backfire ignited the straw and the heat from this burst the sediment bulb intensifying the flames and eventually spreading to the fuel tank which further increased its intensity.

I consider that this was gross neglect and lack of supervision on the part of the school Principal. The tractor should not have been kept in the barn as there are other buildings which could have been utilized for this purpose. Straw should not have been allowed to accumulate around the tractor. While Mr. Card told me the tractor had been used twice a week for chopping grain and cutting wood, it would seem that one full day per week would be sufficient.

I do not feel that the electric wiring should be replaced or the building repaired at this time. Unless there is a change in management I would recommend that this school be closed. I would further recommend that the cultivated land be leased this spring and the day schools built as soon as possible.

Mr. Card denied giving an interview to any newspaper reporter. The only reports were to myself and the R.C.M.P. He emphatically denied stating that he had asked the Indian Affairs Branch for a new tractor. The newspaper report was sent in by Mr. Earl Statesbury of the adjacent Bird's Point resort who was formerly an Editor in Estevaney.

W.J.D. Kerley,
Superintendent.

16-3-50:

3. This date patrol was made via P.O. #8668 to Stockholm, Sask., where the writer was contacted by Cpl. Symonds, patrol then continued to the Round Lake Dist., and subsequent investigation made.

4. The barn in question is 60 ft in length by 20 ft. wide, and housed the milch cows & work horses used by the mission.

5. Investigation disclosed a large area of scorched wood on the ceiling and walls at the rear or west end of the structure. There was no sign of any burning on the floor and the burning portion on the walls was approx. three feet from the floor level, indicating that the flames had flashed upward. 6. Approx. 20 head of cattle were overcome by the smoke from the burning tractor. Total Damage incurred by the fire is approx. $5,000.00

7. Apparently during the cold weather, the tractor has been stored in the rear of the barn to facilitate easier starting of same. The tractor in question is an old Model John Deere machine and was used by the school for instruction of the pupils in proper farming methods. And was used by several of the older boys.

8. On the day of the fire the tractor was operated by one Ronald GEORGE (Age 14) at the end of the day he had driven the tractor into the front of the barn and parked it at the rear near the rear door.

The following is a copy of statement received from Donald George (T.I.).

I am 14 years of age and attend Round Lake Indian Residential School. I have been here for five years. Last fall I started driving one of the tractors at the school. Yesterday March 15th, 1950 we were sawing wood with the tractor. At about 4:00 p.m. we quit and I drove the tractor into the barn. The tractor had been running steady for about one hour sawing wood and was hot. The water in the radiator was boiling. I drove the tractor in the east door and through the barn and stopped just inside the door on the west end. I shut the throttle off and also the gas. The tractor engine stopped almost immediately. It turned over a few times, but was completely stopped by the time I was off the seat and about two or three yards away. I started to leave the barn by the east door. Just as I got to the door I turned to pull the door shut and just as I had pulled the door a couple of feet I noticed flames from the tractor. They appeared to be coming from underneath the gas tank and were shooting up on the left side of the tank. At that time the flame was about as high as the gas tank itself. There were no flames from the right side of the tank or the tractor. I left the door as it was and ran to the residence and yelled that there was a fire on the tractor. Mr. Myles Hoggarth, the farm manager and Murray Wilson, the engineer and some others were having lunch in the kitchen. They all ran to the barn to help fight the fire and to get the stock out of the barn. I was not smoking yesterday when I put the tractor in the barn and did not have any matches in my pockets. As a matter of fact I haven't had a smoke since Xmas holidays. I believe the fire started from a spark from a spark plug or the wiring. There was quite a bit of gas leaking from the glass bowl underneath the gas tank. This gas used to drip and run down the pipe to the carburetor and then drip down on the side of the engine near the spark plug. This same tractor caught on fire last fall when I was one-waying in the field. The fire started that time underneath the carburetor on the left side. I jumped off the tractor and threw some dirt on the blaze which was only about five or six inches high and put it out. Albert MacArthur was fixing fence about a mile away and I went and got him to start the tractor for me. I told him about the tractor catching on fire, but didn't tell the farm manager as he was on Xmas holidays at the time. This tractor is a John Deere and is quite old. There has always been a leak near the glass bowl under the tank ever since I have been driving the tractor and the side of the engine was most always wet with gas under the carburetor. After I notified the men of the fire I went back to the barn with them and helped them fight fire. I carried water and caught a team of horses which we were going to use to pull the tractor out of the barn, however they got another tractor and pulled it out of with that.

Dear Sir:

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School.

The above school was visited on March 23rd by Indian Agent Kerley, D. G. N. Morrison and myself. Mr. Kerley was most anxious that we visit this school and note its general condition.

The school is operated by the W.M.S. of the United Church of Canada with Rev. Card as principal. There are only 62 pupils in attendance.

The main portion of the school building was constructed about 50 years ago and additions have been made since that time, although none of these have been built within the last 30 years. The building is of frame construction throughout - and is in very poor condition. Externally, numerous windows are broken out, the roof sags, the wooden shingles on the roof are poor, the concrete work in the foundations and steps is cracked and doors to the outside entrances to the basement are off their hinges. Internally, while for the most part the school seemed clean, many things are outdated or in poor condition. In a bathroom, in the boys' dormitory, the floor has been partially removed to facilitate some plumbing repairs but has not been relaid. In the boys' playroom, the water and heat has been shut off as the room could not be kept warm due to broken windowpanes and drafty doors. There were numerous places throughout the building where the plaster was falling from the wall.

In all parts of the building, the great fire hazard is most noticeable. Evidence of a fire having started in the boiler room wall can be seen. Only extremely prompt action could prevent a catastrophe.
in this room. A new boiler has been installed within the last year or two but the feed door is warped preventing its locking. This is done by a wooden pole which is propped against the door from the woodpile immediately in front of the boiler.

The fire escapes (fireman type) are accessible through windows. The school is lighted by a 32 volt Delco plant which is housed in a small shed, some 75 feet from the main building. In this building we found an uncovered pail of gasoline, beside a stove which showed signs of having been burning earlier in the day. A new set of batteries has recently been purchased for this lighting plant. At several places in the wiring throughout the building, somewhere connections had fused.

The outbuildings with the exception of the barn appear in a run-down condition. The granaries are leaning in all directions with doors partially off their hinges; the fences are in poor shape and the electric wires carrying power to the barn and pig pen are about six feet above the ground.

The barn, which was constructed last year, was partially destroyed by fire about six weeks ago. The fire originated from a tractor which was stored in the barn in cold weather. About 75% of the electric wiring in the barn will have to be replaced, but there is very little damage to the barn itself. This building is in good condition. Fire extinguishers from the school were used to extinguish the fire in the barn. They were taken to Whiteswood to be recharged. Although they had been ready for 2 or 3 days, no one from the school had taken them out.

The fire hazard at this school should be definitely checked by a fire inspector, as I am of the opinion the building is unsafe. From the age and the general run-down condition of the school, it would appear quite reasonable that the school be closed immediately.

The only redeeming feature of the school is its location. The buildings are on a shelf on the north side overlooking Round Lake, which is approximately 300 feet distant. The land slopes gradually down to the lake affording excellent drainage.

Yours truly,

W. J. Kerr

Dear Doctor Dorey:

The Superintendent of Education has given me a full report on his recent discussions with Mrs. Loveys and yourself concerning the future of this school.

Since then, I have received two very disturbing reports, one from our engineers and the other from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

I am attaching a copy of the report from the Department of Resources and Development and would draw your attention particularly to the following features which are indicative of poor management and organization on the part of the school principal and staff:

(1) Numerous broken window panes;

(2) The very dangerous fire hazard which exists and the apparent lack of discipline which has resulted in the warping of the door on the new boiler;
(3) The uncovered pail of gasoline;
(4) The failure to obtain the fire extinguishers when refilled;
(5) The dilapidated condition of the buildings generally.

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police report covers the circumstances which recently resulted in the second fire at this school. Pertinent extracts are as follows:

"Subject stated that on a recent visit to the school he had noted an open container part full of hi-test gasoline sitting on the floor of a store room and in the adjacent room Indian children were doing the laundry. He advised that it was a well known fact that the Indian boys smoked whenever the opportunity afforded itself. Dear Mr. Harris:

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 9th wherein you set forth certain proposals relating to the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

For your information would say that for some time past I have been rather concerned with the particular problem that the operation of this school has presented. As stated in your letter, I have been fully aware of the poor management in evidence.

My first comment would be that in view of the fact that the school term is almost completed and also the fact that the weather is much warmer, which would naturally necessitate less heating of the building, I believe it would be wise to work out some scheme whereby school could be kept open until the end of June. The way this could be done would be to appoint a night watchman full time for the next two months and then we would be sure that no fire or calamity would befall the inmates. Should this proposal be received kindly, I would at this time recommend Thomas Miskiman of Broadview, whom your Agent in that area could contact and put to work for this particular job.

I am quite in accord with your views as expressed regarding the appointment of an educational survey committee to review the facts at hand in regard to this school. My own views of course are that as soon as conveniently possible that it is wise to do away with all residential schools and get down to a day school basis. In the experience that I have had and advice from those working closely with Indians, I am inclined to believe that day schools are one of the basic solutions to the Indian problem. I quite agree that many more isolated areas...
require the residential type of school but for general purposes, I cannot too strongly urge the doing away with of residential schools.

In consideration of the foregoing therefore, I would suggest that no time be lost in getting your board established and a decision arrived at. Should the committee decide in favour of the day schools, these will have to be built some time during the summer so that the children do not have to suffer, all haste is necessary to get this project started.

Trusting that these observations are of service and assuring you of my continued interest,

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School.

The above school was visited on March 23rd by
Indian Agent Kerley, D. G. N. Morrison and myself. Mr. Kerley
was most anxious that we visit this school and note its
general condition.

The school is operated by the W.M.S. of the United
Church of Canada with Rev. Card as principal. There are only
62 pupils in attendance.

The main portion of the school building was
constructed about 50 years ago and additions have been made since
that time, although none of these have been built within the
last 30 years. The building is of frame construction throughout -
and is in very poor condition. Externally, numerous windows are
broken out, the roof sags, the wooden shingles on the roof are
poorly fitted, concrete work in the foundations and steps is cracked
and doors to the outside entrances to the basement are off their
hinges. Internally, while for the most part the school seemed
clean, many things are out-dated or in poor condition. In a
bathroom, off the boys' dormitory, the floor has been partially
removed to facilitate some plumbing repairs but has not been
replaced. In the boys' playroom, the water and heat has been
shut off as the room could not be kept warm due to broken window-
panes and drafty doors. There were numerous places throughout
the building where the plaster was falling from the wall.

In all parts of the building, the great fire
hazard is most noticeable. Evidence of a fire having started in
the boiler room wall can be seen. Only extremely prompt action
could prevent a catastrophe in this room. A new boiler has
been installed within the last year or two but the feed door is
warped preventing its locking. This is done by a wooden pole
which is propped against the door from the woodpile immediately
in front of the boiler. The fire escapes (fireman type) are accessible through windows. The school is lighted by a 32 volt Delco plant which is housed in a small shed, some 75 feet from the main building. In this building we found an uncovered pail of gasoline, beside a stove which showed signs of having been burning earlier in the day. A new set of batteries has recently been purchased for this lighting plant. At several places in the wiring throughout the building, we saw where connections had fused.

The outbuildings with the exception of the barn appear in a run-down condition. The granaries are leaning in all directions with doors partially off their hinges; the fences are in poor shape, and the electric wires carrying power to the barn and pig pen are about six feet above the ground.

The barn, which was constructed last year, was partially destroyed by fire about six weeks ago. The fire originated from a tractor which was stored in the barn in cold weather. About 75% of the electric wiring in the barn will have to be replaced, but there is very little damage to the barn itself. This building is in good condition. Fire extinguishers from the school were used to extinguish the fire in the barn. They were taken to Whitewood to be recharged. Although they had been ready for 2 or 3 days, no one from the school had taken them out.

The fire hazard at this school should be definitely checked by a fire inspector, as I am of the opinion the building is unsafe. From the age and the general run-down condition of the school, it would appear quite reasonable that the school be closed immediately.

The only redeeming feature of the school is its location. The buildings are on a shelf on the north side overlooking Round Lake, which is approximately 300 feet distant. The land slopes gradually down to the lake affording excellent drainage.

Yours truly,

W. J. Kerr,
Engineering and Construction Service.

Dear Major MacKay:

Your correspondence regarding the Indian Residential School at Round Lake has been received and the Woman's Missionary Society is very disturbed that the closing of this School should be considered almost immediately.

We have known that the health of our principal has been poor but it was impossible for us to get a medical report which would say that he should not continue his work and at no time has the Department definitely told us that a change should be made, until I had a conversation on the telephone with Mr. Ostrander, when I was in Regina in February. We took action immediately and told Mr. Card that his services would terminate on June 30th.

As far as the condition of the School is concerned, you may recall that we have been requesting a new School for 15 years, knowing that the present one was in poor condition. While no steps were taken toward building, we always received encouragement and we were definitely told that the building of the Round Lake School was high on the list of new buildings.

While we have accepted responsibility for the staff and we know the condition of Mr. Card's health, we understood that the supervision of the School was under the Department of Indian Affairs and if the school buildings are in such poor condition, we should have been made aware of this by those who have been supervising.

While we believe in the Day School Program, we cannot overlook the fact that our schools are being closed too quickly and our constituency will not accept the closing of Round Lake without protest.

From last September until February, the children were
without schools at File Hills and again at Round Lake these children would be without any supervision of schooling if the school were closed in June.

I am writing Dr. Dorey, who is now in Saskatoon, and trust that you may hear again from him in the course of a few days.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Re: Round Lake Indian Residential School,

The above school was visited on March 23rd by Indian Agent Kerley, D. G. N. Morrison and myself. Mr. Kerley was most anxious that we visit this school and note its general condition.

The school is operated by the U.M.C. of the United Church of Canada with Rev. Card as principal. There are only 62 pupils in attendance.

The main portion of the school building was constructed about 50 years ago and additions have been made since that time, although none of these have been built within the last 30 years. The building is of frame construction throughout and is in very poor condition. Externally, numerous windows are broken out, the roof sags, the wooden shingles on the roof are poor, the concrete work in the foundations and steps is cracked and due to the weather expansion joints have opened and their hinges. Internally, while for the most part the school seems clean, many things are out-dated or in poor condition. In a bathroom, off the boys' dormitory, the floor has been partially removed to facilitate some plumbing repairs but has not been relaid. In the boys' playroom, the water and heat has been shut off as the room could not be kept warm due to broken window-panes and drafty doors. There were numerous places throughout the building where the plaster was falling from the wall.

In all parts of the building, the great fire hazard is most noticeable. Evidence of a fire having started in the boiler room wall can be seen. Only extremely prompt action could prevent a catastrophe in this room. A new boiler has been installed within the last year or two but the feed door is warped preventing its locking. This is done by a wooden pole which is propped against the door from the woodpile immediately
in front of the boiler. The fire escapes (fireman type) are accessible through windows. The school is lighted by a 32 volt Belco plant which is housed in a small shed, some 75 feet from the main building. In this building we found an uncovered pail of gasoline, beside a stove which showed signs of having been burning earlier in the day. A new set of batteries has recently been purchased for this lighting plant. At several places in the wiring throughout the building, we saw where connections had fused.

The outbuildings with the exception of the barn appear in a run-down condition. The granaries are leaning in all directions with doors partially off their hinges; the fences are in poor shape, and the electric wires carrying power to the barn and pig pen are about six feet above the ground.

The barn, which was constructed last year, was partially destroyed by fire about six weeks ago. The fire originated from a tractor which was stored in the barn in cold weather. About 75% of the electric wiring in the barn will have to be replaced, but there is very little damage to the barn itself. This building is in good condition. Fire extinguishers from the school were used to extinguish the fire in the barn. They were taken to Whitewood to be recharged. Although they had been ready for 2 or 3 days, no one from the school had taken them out.

The fire hazard at this school should be definitely checked by a fire inspector, as I am of the opinion the building is unsafe. From the age and the general run-down condition of the school, it would appear quite reasonable that the school be closed immediately.

The only redeeming feature of the school is its location. The buildings are on a shelf on the north side overlooking Round Lake, which is approximately 300 feet distant. The land slopes gradually down to the lake affording excellent drainage.

Yours truly,

H. J. Kerr,
Engineering and Construction Service.

You are probably aware of the proposed composition of the committee which is:

...
(a) A Branch official
(b) A provincial education official

There will, therefore, likely be two committees, each deliberating on those school matters with which each of the two larger denominations is concerned. It may be possible, however, for the travelling and exploration to be done by all the members of the committee together so as to save the time of certain officials, but this consideration is at the option of the ecclesiastical members of the committee.

The duration of the sittings, travelling, hearings, etc., will depend upon the completeness of the information available from recently prepared maps, statistics and reports, and the number of persons who wish to be heard by the committee(s). We must try to avoid any long procession of Indian individuals who desire to make representations, and at the same time avoid being influenced by petitions, signed by many although engineered by only a few.

In surveys conducted elsewhere by the Department white residents of the area have offered or been invited to give their views especially when such persons have a professional or official political relation to local education such as inspectors or trustees.

Certain accommodation and conveniences are necessary. The committee members will probably prefer the hotel at Whitewood. In default of a recording device, a shorthand writer will be desirable at several sessions. A place for the committee to meet in privacy will be necessary—a place furnished sufficiently to permit a few visitors at a time. Transportation will, of course, be required. Favourable weather is something for which we shall hope, and we shall hope also not to disturb unduly the ordinary business of the agency which is probably great enough at this season.

Reverend Father Piche of Qu'Appelle school is already designated as a member of the committee and the ecclesiastical authorities of the area are all probably aware of the intended survey. It would seem in order, therefore, to acquaint the Chiefs and Councillors with what is intended, although the dates have still to be determined.

I visited this school on the 8th. It is situated in the Qu'Appelle Valley at the east end of Round Lake just across the river from the Ochapowace reserve. It is under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church. The Staff consists of the Principal, the Rev. Mr. Greer, Mrs. Ed. Garrett, teacher, Mr. Ed. Garrett, Farming Instructor, Miss N. Campbell, Matron, Mrs. C. Burgess, Assistant Matron, Mrs. Goth, Cook and Miss Handford, Laundress. At the time of my visit there were 68 children on the register comprising the following grades,

| Standard | I. | II. | III. | IV. | VII. |
|----------|----|-----|------|-----|------|
|          | 26 | 7   | 15   | 19  | 68   |

The day of my visit there were only 51 present, 17 being absent on the reserve. Mr. Murison inspected this school on June 6th and 7th last year and in his report he gives a comprehensive description of the building and the equipment and at that time he recommended several changes in the lay-out of the school but to date no changes have been made. I must say that this is one of the worst managed institutions I have visited in an official capacity since I have been with the Department. To me it appeared like a ship on the ocean without a rudder, even the staff were quarrelling among themselves and are divided into two factions. The Principal is about to retire, therefore, there was no use of my finding fault with the management of the school as he
informed me that he did not intend to make any changes and that it would be up to the new Principal. Mr. Greer has been there since sometime last summer and from his conversation I gathered that he endeavoured to take steps to straighten this out when he first went there but met with opposition from some of the staff and as he had no authority to discharge them he threw up his hands and let things drift. You can imagine the lack of discipline at this institution. What the school needs is a first class principal, who will not be dictated to by outsiders and a man with some backbone and good common sense. There is so much at fault with both the building and the management that it is useless to criticize the institution from any one angle. I will just mention a few of the essential points.

The new Principal, I was advised, would arrive about the 6th of June, upon his arrival he should be properly instructed as to what is expected of him by the Department and several changes will have to be made in the staff as those who are there now certainly cannot work together. I learned that the Department contemplate making several changes in the building. Before this is done a competent engineer should examine the building. The dormitories are too small and too many children sleep in one room and most of the girls are sleeping two in a bed. The furnaces are too small to heat the buildings. The laundry is poorly equipped and is inadequate. The Girls'
dormitories were fairly clean but the boys untidy and the bed clothes dirty. The children were fairly well clothed but untidy. The grounds around the buildings were untidy. No provision is made in the school for the isolation of any case of sickness.

At the time of my visit one girl was ill in the girls' dormitory. The supply of water for the school is taken from the lake and is pumped from there into a tank in the building. The water pipes were only put down 12" under ground and this means that they freeze up every winter and a new set of pipes has to be purchased. The pump house with the engine was evidently stationed on the ice this winter, when the ice melted the pump house was not moved and is now half under water. The day I was there, Mr. Hillhouse, our Farming Instructor, was with me and he tried to pull the house ashore but had not sufficient power and unless they find some way of moving it they will be compelled to carry the water from the lake.

The work in the class rooms is very poor. Mrs. Garrett I presume would be a fair teacher in a small country school but the class she has is entirely too large for her. There is only one class room and the children attend so irregularly that their progress is very slow. The discipline in the school room is poor and it was difficult to hear what the children were saying. They would not speak up so they could be heard.

Sir:

I beg to make the following report on Schools in the Crooked Lake Agency.

ROUND LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL:

I visited this school on November 29 which is under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church with the Reverend J.A. Ross in charge as Principal and his wife who acts as Matron and teacher for the Junior classes. Miss Carruthers who has second class professional standing teaches the senior classes, Miss E.M. Quirk is cook, Mrs. S. McIntyre laundress and Mrs. S. Runacres seamstress. Mr. Philp has been engaged as farmer and his wife who is a graduate Nurse will take up the work of Nursing Matron when she arrives; they are expected at an early date.

There are seventy-two pupils enrolled forty one girls and thirty one boys, there were thirty four girls and twenty six boys present on the day of my visit, twelve were absent on account of sickness, three of these have attained the age of eighteen years. The pupils presented a fairly clean appearance. I found three girls sick in bed.

with chickenpox; there is no accommodation at this school for isolation in case of sickness and these children are sleeping in the same dormitory with the rest of the girl pupils, I commented on this and the Principal stated that the Doctor said that as the children had already come in contact with the disease it was possibly just as well that it should be permitted to run its course as no doubt they would get it anyway.

BUILDINGS:

The school room which was a detached building was recently burned down together with all the desks and school equipment and classes are now being held in the play rooms, they have a few old desks, some with broken legs which are very inadequate and I found the children sitting on the lockers in the play room. Teaching under these conditions is a difficult matter and I would suggest that forty-eight single desks be supplied. They would be available later when class room accommodation is provided. The new portion of the main building is much brighter since it has been re-modelled, it does not however provide adequate accommodation for the pupilage and staff. They are very cramped for room. The septic tank has been giving excellent satisfaction, the laundry is too small to permit of installing proper laundry equipment, the facilities have been improved however by the installation of sett tubs and a hot water heater, a new chimney has also been built from the laundry to replace the old galvanized one and this has added considerably to the safety of the building from the danger of fire. The old portion of the school at the rear of the new addition is of very little use, it can only be described as a rookery, being cut up with small rooms and dark holes and corners, radiation was installed in this
portion of the building when the new furnace was put in but it is found impossible to heat them and a heating stove has been placed in the sewing room. I think it would be a mistake to spend any money in trying to re-model this portion of the building, it would be better to tear it down and add to the main building, it will be necessary to provide class room accommodation and it appears to me that it would be better to add class rooms on to the main building rather than erect another separate school as the upstairs accommodation could be utilized to good advantage. The pumping and electric light installations have so far been giving good satisfaction. The water is pumped from a soakage well located at the edge of the Round Lake into a pressure tank in the school, it may be necessary to enlarge the reservoir so as to provide larger storage capacity for water.

FARM:

The farm in connection with this school consists of half a section of land about half of which is in the valley, they raised this year 635 bushels of wheat and 750 bushels of oats. They had a large garden which provided an ample quantity of potatoes and vegetables for the requirements at the school. They have 51 head of cattle, 5 hogs and a small flock of poultry, they are milking 11 cows and are getting about 40 quarts of milk a day. This provides milk for porridge and tea as well as some to drink. I made enquiry into the food provided the children and it appears to be very satisfactory. For breakfast they have porridge with milk and sugar, bread and jam, tea with milk and sugar in it and milk for the smaller children. For dinner they have meat, two kinds of vegetables, pudding, bread and lard and tea. Their fare for supper is varied, macaroni and tomatoes, potatoes, bread and butter with peanut butter or jam. Their appearance would indicate that they are getting
plenty of good wholesome food.

GENERAL:

I was informed that the Church have purchased the four hundred acres of land adjoining the school from the Reverend Doctor McKay, there is a good house on this land which will be used by the Principal as a residence when it becomes available which is expected very soon.

COWESSES BOARDING SCHOOL:

This school is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church with the Reverend Father Carriere as Principal. The inside work of the school is managed by six Sisters of Charity, two of whom act as teachers. The Reverend Sister Saint Pierre Chrysologue is in charge of the boys' class room and the Reverend Sister Areenius in charge of the girls' class room, these Sisters have Quebec model school training. The first mentioned I am told was a teacher at the Normal school in Quebec for eight years. Their methods might not be considered up-to-date by a public school inspector but the progress being made in the class rooms by the pupils appeared very satisfactory to me, the children spoke up clearly and distinctly, were quick in answering questions and the discipline in the school room was excellent. There were 32 boys and 35 girls present on the date of my visit and they presented a clean and tidy appearance. There were seven children sick with measles, these were isolated from the rest of the pupils. The children receive plenty of exercise, games are indulged in as well as regular fire drill.
The school is a large brick building, it is well equipped with the necessary furniture, laundry equipment, etc., it is steam heated and lighted with electricity. As this school has already been described it is unnecessary to go into details again in this report.

The pupils receive an abundance of good wholesome food, they get all the milk they care to drink. They have 26 milch cows and were milking 12 at the time of my visit. I am told that the number of cows milking is never permitted to be less than ten.

FARM AND GARDEN:

The farm stock consists of about 50 head of cattle, 16 horses, 52 pigs and a large flock of poultry. They had 150 acres in wheat which yielded 1500 bushels, 50 acres of oats, yielded 1500 bushels and 35 acres of barley yielded 600 bushels. They had a large garden which yielded over 500 bushels of potatoes and an ample supply of vegetables for their requirements. This school is well managed, and the pupils are well cared for.

This report is respectfully submitted.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the Crooked Lake Agency which was made by Inspector Murison during the latter part of November.

Dealing with the Round Lake School the Inspector draws attention to the recent fire which destroyed the two new classrooms in connection with the school and points out that the classes are now being held under difficulties without desks or benches. I think probably the Department should consider the matter of furnishing a few desks until such time as it is decided what is to be done in regard to the erection of another classroom. My opinion is that when a class room is erected it should be one storey with two rooms, a plain building 28x45 or 46, with an entrance at either end, one for the senior and one for the junior classes. I believe a building such as we require could be erected for about six thousand dollars or maybe less. I mention this in order that an amount may be placed in the estimates if it is our duty to build this. You might advise me in this connection.

Inspector reports that the children are well fed and are getting an ample supply of milk daily, which is a good thing.

REGINA, SASK., July 10th, 1926

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report of a visit which I made to the Round Lake and Cowessess Indian Boarding Schools when making my recent inspection of the Crooked Lakes Agency. The pupils were all absent on their holidays and I will, therefore, confine my remarks to the condition of the buildings and premises.

ROUND LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL

This school is under the auspices of the United Church of Canada, with the Rev. R. J. Ross in charge as Principal. I am pleased to report that I found conditions very greatly improved since my last inspection in June one year ago. The main building has been re-painted outside, and the interior walls re-decorated. An additional pressure tank has been installed in connection with the water supply and the old cistern is now being used as well, for water storage in case of emergency. The Principal informs me that the system has been found quite satisfactory. The furnace boiler was cracked, owing to allowing the water to get too low, and the broken sections have had to be replaced. The repairs are on the ground but have not yet been put in place. The school was clean and tidy throughout.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,

GENERAL

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the classroom activity generally and offer any suggestions for improvement)

The senior was operated on a shift system. In the morning a part of the classes attended school while the other was engaged in husbandry and household duties. I was informed by the Principal that this was the plan of conducting the education. All subjects of the curriculum were included in the time-table but in some cases provision was made for subjects only once a week; under the system this was the only thing that could happen in the senior's five classes.

In this department there were four girls and three boys who attended school separately morning and afternoon, the policy being to give every advantage to those who were willing to take an education and who were making an exceptionally good showing in their studies.

The Junior room gave evidence of a lack of organized work; a large part of the classes were without exercise books and only a few of those who had them were showing any signs of advancement. This room is making very little progress under the present arrangement and is in my opinion, urgently in need of a fully qualified and experienced teacher.
