Report of Inspection on Round Lake Residential School.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I visited this school on December 17th., last, and made a general inspection of buildings and premises. The school is under the auspices of the United Church, with the Rev. R. J. Ross in charge as Principal. His staff is comprised of Mrs. Heron, Matron, Mrs. Ross and Miss Murray, teachers, Miss Jury, cook, Miss Rowan, seamstress, Miss Ewen, laundress, and David Bushnell, farmer. There are 75 pupils enrolled, 35 boys and 40 girls, which is the limit for which accommodation is provided. I was present at the midday meal, and noted that an ample supply of wholesome food was provided. I visited both classrooms, and found the pupils comfortably clad and presenting a healthy appearance. Mrs. Ross continues to teach in the senior classroom and appears to be a competent teacher. Miss Murray, who has charge of the junior classroom, impresses me as being well qualified for the position, and is the most successful teacher they have had in this room for some time.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
BUILDINGS.

The school building has already been reported on very fully, and there is no change in the main features. The laundry is very cramped for space, and a lack of convenience for drying the clothes still exists. The roots and vegetables are stored in the same place in this building, and although authority was granted to build an outside root house, and the Principal has been urged from time to time to proceed with the work, this root house has not yet been built. The Principal states that he could not get around to it, owing to pressure of work, and the illness of his assistant. During the past summer the facilities for fire protection have been greatly added to. The piping in the pole escapes has been replaced with a larger size, and the windows forming the exits have been equipped with hooks which can be easily opened. Four 5-gallon pump extinguishers have been supplied. A soft water tank in the basement is being utilized for water storage, and the water is pumped to this with a windmill, which appears to be giving excellent service. A 1000-gallon pressure tank has been twinned up with the 500-gallon tank which is part of the old equipment, and this makes it possible to utilize the water system through the standpipe which has also been installed. This equipment is new and in excellent condition. The new portion of the school building has been re-decorated, and the plaster is in good shape. In the old portion the plaster is broken and the floors are old and this part is very hard to heat. I found the school in a cleanly condition throughout. I was better satisfied in this connection than I have been on the occasion of former visits.
Report of Inspection at Round Lake Residential School.

The exteriors of both the class room and the main building require re-painting. Since my last visit a new barn, 32 x 70, has been built. This barn is not large enough for all their young stock, and 16 cattle were running outside. I would suggest that a leanto shed would provide satisfactory accommodation for the young stock. The old stone stables are still standing, and are being used to accommodate the hogs. These old buildings do not add to the appearance of the place, which would be much improved if they were torn down and a suitable piggery provided. They have a small poultry house, 16 x 16, which provides accommodation for fifty hens. They should have at least three times this number of poultry at a school of this size.

FARM STOCK.

The farm stock consists of 12 horses, 51 cattle and 70 hogs, 13 of which are purebred. They were milking eight cows, only three of which were giving any quantity, and the milk supply is not adequate to provide the children with all they care to drink. The farm stock provides practically all the meat requirements of the institution.

FARM.

Their crop sown comprised 60 acres of wheat, which yielded 1500 bushels, 60 acres of oats, yielding 2500 bushels, 40 acres barley, yielding 1000 bushels, and 38 acres of rye, with a yield of 700 bushels. REGINA, SASK., 10th January, 1929.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the Round Lake Indian Residential School, in the Crooked Lake Agency, which was inspected on December 17th last by Mr. Murison.

Conditions at this school seem to be a little bit improved since the last inspection. Some of the buildings here are old, and it is hard to make them look up-to-date. I do not feel like making a recommendation for the expenditure of any money on these buildings. Authority was granted some time early in the year to build a root house, but you will note that nothing has been done in regard to this and, of course, the result will be that the money voted will not be used. The Agent was in my office this week and I told him he should at least buy the material and have it on hand so that the money would be spent before March 31st.

I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding the barn. My opinion is that this barn is quite large enough for any school, and I am not in favour of putting up a lot of small buildings to accommodate additional cattle. 51 head of cattle is too many to have on hand at a school of this kind. I would judge from the crop yield that the farming is carried on in a satisfactory manner. The yield was much better than on the reserve, which shows that the land was well cultivated.

Yours very truly,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Regina, December 11th, 1941.

Report on Round Lake Indian Residential School

I wish to inform you that I inspected the Round Lake Indian Residential School on December 3rd and am pleased to report that I found this Institution in better shape than ever before.

Buildings

As you know, this Institution has been built up from practically nothing, simply by adding on something here and there. The same applies more or less to the outside buildings. I found everything in good order and all buildings painted, and I was informed that the Department had furnished the material and the Staff had performed the labour. The machinery in the laundry, the boiler, the lighting plant, and the battery were all in first class condition. The only thing I found that required renewing was the sewers throughg. This has been on the building for years and the snow and frost have had the effect that it will have to be renewed next Summer. The tables and the benches in the dining room are also past repairing and the Principal informed me that if he were supplied with material to build new tables and benches the School would perform the labour. The bill of material will be forwarded later on.

Cattle

They have 65 head of Holstein cattle. There were 100 head when Mr. Huston took charge but they are now reduced to 65 and it is his intention to gradually work into a Shorthorn herd and get rid of the Holsteins. He also intends to further reduce the herd to about 40 or 50. I think this is a step in the right direction. They also have 13 horses which I consider that they do not need because they have a tractor to do the farm work, and the Principal informed me that he would get rid of some of the useless horses he has there.

Gardens

The crop was poor last Summer on account of drouth and the Principal has had to buy potatoes and other vegetables because the amount grown at the School was not sufficient to carry them through the year.

Water

The water used at the School is taken from Round Lake, just adjacent to it, but the water used for drinking, etc., is hauled from a spring about 1½ miles...........

General Comment:

In neither room of this school does the enrolment seem to have been completed. There has evidently been a request made to the Saskatchewan Department of Education to have correspondence courses given to some pupils on a nearby reserve.

Mrs. Linton is a well-qualified, energetic, interested teacher who is trying to bring these pupils to the same standards that one would find in any public school in the province. It is to be noted that pupils from the school are enrolled in high school classes (e.g., Brandon, etc.).

I do not think she feels sympathetic towards these pupils because they are Indians. If she were to be asked why she would probably ask: Why should I be? Her attitude seems to be that they are as well equipped mentally as other children to carry on with the school work and they should be treated exactly the same and the same results should be expected.

If an explanation is needed for Mrs. Linton's lack of warm community support, the above is offered.

May I add the following.

Mrs. Linton and the children were enjoying one of the evening autumn bonfires that were possible around Hallowe'en this year. She had taught them the one verse of a Hallowe'en song that the book gave and had 'made up' another. They sang the two and then Mrs. Linton suggested that the children 'make up' one of their own—the book had one, she had made up one, so that they had examples to follow. One of the girls spoke for the group when she said, "But, Mrs. Linton, yours doesn't sound made up!"

GENERAL REMARKS:

Visit class room and find affairs in connection running smoothly. Confer with Principal on several matters, particularly re pupil Mary Gaddie who should be kept under closer observation and away from young men of questionable moral character.

I regret to report the death by drowning of a girl pupil, No.0102, Maud Tapewaywaypenasick, aged 15. It appears the deceased along with several more girl pupils during the evening of the 20th went to the large lake which is close by the school to bathe and all of them ventured by the method of joining hands too far out in the deep water. As is usual in such unfortunate daring cases the girls became afraid too late, and on the hand chain being broked several were in great danger of being drowned. One of the girls, Ida Sagit, acted in a very heroic manner and by her presence of mind and actions although in great danger herself saved at least two girls. These girl pupils were unaccompanied by any of the staff connected with the school, which is to be regretted. The police and coroner investigated the matter, and afterwards made reports to their respective departments.

AGENT'S REPORT

Respecting the Round Lake Indian Residential School
For the month of April 1929

ROUTINE

At the time of my visit there were:
- 71 pupils in the classrooms.
- Are the classroom registers kept up to date? Yes.
- 1 pupil in vocational training departments.
- 1 pupil sick.
- 5 pupils absent. Reasons: at home helping parents.
- Total number on roll: 77.

Are there any pupils in residence whose admission has not been approved by the Department?
No.

HEALTH, SANITATION, Etc.

Appearance of pupils: clean and neat and well clothed. Many just recovered from influenza and still showing effects.
Cleanliness of school: main buildings and classrooms bathed, clean and well kept.
Appearance of school grounds: rather untidy; wood piled in playground; the principal was drawn to this and improvement expected.
Care of the sick: sick children receive all possible care and attention.
The children's meals: the children have plenty of good wholesome food at all times.
Fire drill, escapes and protection: fire-drill held fairly regularly and house and other places.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING

Domestic Instruction: from about the age of 11 years.
Instruction in Farming and Gardening: from the age of about 12 years.
Training in the care of live stock: 12 years.
Manual training: a few of the older boys assist at general repair work.
Care of agricultural machinery and other equipment: the older boys are taught to operate the implements and machinery after the age of about 12 years.

GENERAL

Discipline at the school: fairly good.
Efficiency of the staff: at the present time the staff are quite efficient.
General management: good financially.

Suggestions: more organized games are needed; this is a feature which has not been given much attention at this school; I would suggest that a foot-ball be purchased for the boys and basketball for the girls, and that the school staff make more effort to encourage the children to take proper exercise at their play-time.

April 23rd 1888

Sir,

My object in writing is to ask if you can do anything for us in the way of procuring a piece of land for the benefit of our school. There is the S.W. of Sec. 28 Township 18 R. 3. This would be valuable to us or failing in this, the S.E. of the same 23rd Sec. or Sec. 13 in the same Township. These lands are still unoccupied & without improvement.

L. Van Boughnet,
Deputy Sup't General of Indian Affairs
I spoke to the new Governor about this matter last summer. His reply was that the land had already been taken up. The field however unoccupied & if it can be purchased our school will be vastly much strengthened.

I have also been encouraged by our Agent Col. MacDonald & by Dr. Macdonald, Inspector of Indian Schools to make application to the Department for a school some day. Application just little appear in due time.

I have been making your proposed improvements in Indian schools.

Perhaps I suggest that instead of erecting & building us 4 schools on Crooked Lakes Reserve, our present school at Round Lake be strengthened so as to accommodate the children of school age on the farm Reserve.

The value the school buildings already here at $5000 & which together with barns, stables, cattle etc., will amount to...
$6000.00 we have sufficient-room to accommodate all the girls on those reserves (75). Now if we had suit the buildings for the boys we would be ready for the work. Then in regard to the support of the school, the Church is prepared to give $1800.00 per an. in support of those in charge of the work and also clothe the children. So the expense resting upon the Government would not be much more than it would be in keeping up 4 common schools. In following this plan we would have a better opportunity of accomplishing the work at which we aim viz the Civilization & Christianising of the boy Indian.

1st the children are taken away from the pernicious influences of the pagan wigwam & constantly under our care.

2nd we have regular attendance.

3 Opportunity of teaching economy & self-support.

The girls find employment in knitting, sewing, various kinds of housework and the boys in the gardens or the army or taking care of cattle.
To try to give each child who enters the school an opportunity of rising first at the table, he may work for a better position, thus for better clothing & better sleeping department, and for higher positions in the society of our home. If a child has any ambitions she will rise until he wishes to become self-supporting. If he has none he will soon become weary of our home go back & spend his life in pauperism & die in the wigwam.

In I trust you will pardon me for writing, but I feel for the founders. I am ashamed to think of how little our church has done for this poor people, but I trust that the day is not far distant when by the united effort of Church & government all the Indian children of the N.W.T. will be gathered in four papamies & made useful citizens.

I have the honour to be

Your humble servant,

Hilltopp.

Dear Sir,

The Round Lake Indian Boarding School, which has been carried on for the past ten years under the principalship of the Rev. Hugh McKay, finds itself crippled for want of a sufficient amount of farming land, and I am instructed by our Committee to ask you to use your influence to have an additional quantity of land set apart for the purpose of the school. The need of arable land at the school is so great that for several years a neighboring farm from which the proprietor had moved away has been rented and cultivated chiefly by the labor of the boys who are pupils in the school.

(2nd) The land in question lies partly in the valley of the Qu'Appelle River and partly on the high prairie level above the valley. The hill which bounds the valley and which is about 200 feet high, runs through the land for which we ask and renders a considerable part of
this area almost useless for agricultural purposes.

(3rd) The Indian Department I am sure will agree with our Committee that it is very desirable to have the Indian boys instructed in the care of cattle, a kind of industry to which they take much more kindly than to the growing of crops. MEMO FOR FILE:

The ROUND LAKE BOARDING SCHOOL was built by the Presbyterian Church, on fractional N.E. quarter of Section 14, Tp. 18, Rge. 3, West End. Some acres had been acquired by them.

As early as 1892 church authorities, in conjunction with this Department, endeavoured, through the Department of the Interior, to secure the S. § of fractions, Section 15 for the C.F.R.R. for school purposes. This effort was abortive for some years, and the land purchase was initiated with a view to securing the N. § of 15 which was held in 1890 by the Canada North West Land Company. In the course of the latter negotiations, it was found that the S. § of 15 was available, and as this was the property that was originally requested, correspondence was continued until 1899 when, by P.C. 667, dated the first of May, the property was vested in the Department of Indian Affairs for the purposes of the Round Lake Indian Boarding School.

It is proposed, at this time, to purchase the church property at this institution and, further, to secure the house and farm of the Rev. Dr. McKay, for many years the Principal of the school. A description of Dr. McKay's property is not on file. It is my opinion that he has title to the N. § of Section 14, plus some additional 60 acres. Dr. Edmison, in a communication dated November 23rd, last, states that "Judge Farrell advises me that Dr. McKay's farm and house are worth $17,000," and he further suggests that the Department reimburse the Church for their building equity and land on which it stands to the extent of about $10,000. Judge Farrell, in a letter to Dr. McKay in communication to Dr. Edmison dated the 26th ultimo, states that the Doctor will not likely accept $12,000 for his 406 acres. Rev. Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 16th instant, No. 108-1-9, in connection with the proposed erection of a church building for the United Church, I beg to say that the school premises is not the most central site for the Protestant Indians of this Agency, and it would be impossible to find a more central site than that of the old church building on the Kankewiskanaw Reserve.

There are many arguments, pro and con, in connection with the site for the new church building, but I think the strongest argument in favour of a site near the school is the fact that it is impossible at times for the missionary to get to the Kankewiskanaw Reserve for church service as a result of bad weather, bad roads, and the many other occurrences which come unexpectedly and make it inconvenient for the Principal or a residential school to be absent from his school for several hours. I might observe, however, that it has never appeared to me that the appointments of Principal of the Residential School and Missionary to a large number of Indians on the near reserves should be combined as either one or the other suffers. Some Principals look upon the school work as the more important and allow the missionary work to suffer; others look upon the missionary work as the more important and allow the school affairs to suffer. I believe that, in this case, there would certainly be a more regular church service if the church building were near the school. It would not be as convenient for a number of the Indians, yet I think it is better for the minister to go to church and find a small congregation than for a large congregation to go to church and find no minister.

As you know, we had no crop whatever last year. We had no straw for bedding except two old stacks on top of the hill. We repaired an old road in order to get this straw down. We asked the Land Department of the C.P.R. if they would sell the two portions of this quarter-section we required for our purpose. In their reply, they intimated that they would dispose of the quarter in its entirety to the first satisfactory applicant. We offered $750 and bought it.

We were influenced by the fact that on this quarter-section there is a small spring and we have a pasture of approximately 400 acres adjoining it, on which there is no water supply.

65 acres of this land is in the hills and has not much value. 35 acres can be broken and is good land. 40 acres of this has been cropped.

There are two small buildings, a house and a barn. The barn...
will accommodate eight horses. Both buildings seem in good repair.

Heretofore, we have been dependent on the reserve for much of our summer pasture. Now our herd is accredited and we cannot let them mingle with other cattle. Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th. It is re N.W.Q Sec. 27, Tp. 18, R. 2, W. S. 1.

In a personal letter dated June 7th, 1932, Mr. Russell T. Perrier informed me that title to the north half of the above Section should be made out in the name of "His Majesty the King as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs" if school funds were being used in the purchase. I accordingly sent to the Department the application to purchase the N.W. Quarter. We have already paid the purchase money. All we wish is the signature.

This personal letter was in reply to a letter I had written to Mr. J.P. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Breadview, Sask., setting forth our reasons for the purchase of this property and asking that the Department re-imburse the school when times became normal again.

The C.P.R. had leased the N.W. Quarter and could not sell until the lease had expired. Therefore we did not buy both Quarters at the same time.

Yours Truly,

R.J. Ross,
Principal Round Lake Indian Residential School.

Sir:

I beg to ask you if it would be possible for you to sanction the admission of two children belonging to Charles Rider Jr. of Assiniboine Agency to the Roundlake Residential School.

Charles Rider had the misfortune to lose his wife last December leaving him with a new born son as well as 8 other children, 3 of these children, Rosabel 15 years old, Peter 9 years old and Willie 8 years old are already attending this school.

George Rider 15 years old and James Rider II years old are out of school on account of very poor health.

Edith Rider 2 years old and the baby are being looked after by their grandparents.

The 2 children he is asking admission for are Edward 6 years old and Mary 5 years old. They are both healthy children.

Rev. R.J. Ross, Principal of the Roundlake school has expressed his willingness to accept them at once providing you grant their admission.

As Charles Rider is farming on a fairly large scale he is unable to look after these children properly besides working his farm as it should be done.

It would be a benefit to all concerned if the admittance of these children could be granted at once.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Booth
Acting Indian Agent

With reference to your letter No.108-1-10 of the 4th instant I beg to submit the following information:
I took the matter up with Mr. and Mrs. Denis Wasna regarding sending their eldest daughter Violet to Round Lake Mission and they were very anxious that Violet should attend that school for although Denis Wasna is an adherent to the Roman Catholic Faith, this family since they were married have practically been a Protestant family. This couple was married by the Presbyterian Church in Sintaluta and all their children were baptized by the same church and whenever they went to church it was always Protestant. Violet Wasna attended the Day School on this reserve before going to Round Lake, and has been brought up to the Protestant Faith.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 25th instant, No. 108-1-10, in connection with the transfer of certain children from the Round Lake Indian Residential School to the Brandon Indian Residential School, I beg to say that I was not aware that proper arrangements had not been made for these transfers.

Reverend Mr. Ross telephoned me one day and informed me that he had arranged to transfer these children to the Brandon school and asked me to send transportation for them. I concluded that he meant that he had made arrangements through the Department, but I have since found that the only arrangements made were between himself and the Reverend Principal of the Brandon School. I may say that, had the matter been referred to me for recommendation in the first instance, I would not have recommended the transfer as all the children sent to Brandon school for higher education have proved a failure in the past and I cannot see any reason why these children will prove any better than the others.

With regard to the last paragraph of your letter the pupils referred to as Marthe and Adeline Kay are numbers 0156 and 0159 respectively.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that there was a child adopted by Vincent Pepeech of the Sackinay Band in 1930. The parents of this child were John Pepeech and wife of ticket No. 125, Sackinay Band. After the death of the father the child was given by the mother to Vincent Pepeech, the child's uncle. This child has been on Vincent's ticket since 1930 and was recently placed in the Round Lake Residential School by Vincent.

Rev. Father Carriere, Principal of the Cowessess Residential School, has protested against this child being admitted to the Protestant school as he states that John Pepeech and wife were Roman Catholics and the child was Baptised in the Catholic faith. I have no doubt that Father Carriere can produce proof of this fact, but it would appear to me that the Guardian may still place the child in the school he wishes as he has assumed responsibility for its welfare as the request of the widowed mother.

I have the application for admission signed by Vincent Pepeech for this child, but I shall await a ruling from the Department before forwarding this application as I have never had a case exactly like this to deal with before.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 7th ultimo,
No. 105-1-10, in connection with the admission of adopted child of Vincent Pepeech to the Round Lake Residential School, I beg to say that I have investigated this case thoroughly and, while I am not satisfied with statements received from Vincent Pepeech and Mrs. John Pepeech in this connection, I can see that there is not sufficient grounds for keeping the child in the Round Lake School. The adoption paper, which Vincent Pepeech said had been signed before a Notary Public in Yorkton, is now said to have been lost and there was no copy of it filed with the Notary Public who has no recollection of the transaction in his memory. Mrs. John Pepeech says there was never a paper signed and that she allowed Vincent to keep the child temporarily, and that she does not wish the child to be educated in the Round Lake School and given as her reason that she has been talking to Rev. Father Leonard, Principal of the Qu'Appelle School, and the Reverend Father informed her that boys receive a better training in his school as they learn a trade, while they receive only class-room education at the Round Lake School.

I have taken no action with regard to having the child removed to the Roman Catholic school, but it would appear that no other action can be taken under the circumstances and I shall await the instructions of the Department. I might say that Reverend R.J. Ross, Principal of the Round Lake School, informed me, in conversation some time ago, that he will not let the child go without "putting up a fight for him", but I cannot see that he has any grounds on which to argue the case as there is no proof that any adoption actually took place and the mother, who is a Catholic, says she wishes to have the child continue in the Catholic faith. If there are any Indians who know anything about this adoption they are careful now to give no information to me.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

J.T.E. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

It has been customary for some years in connection with the Round Lake School to have the girls who belong to the C.G.I.T. groups attend the summer camp which is held at Round Lake by the Religious Education Association. Hitherto it has been possible to finance this matter locally but in this year of financial difficulty Rev. R. J. Ross, the Principal, informs us that the work cannot be carried without assistance. They have nineteen girls belonging to this group attending the school and there are six girls who also belong to the group will soon return from Brandon Residential School for their holidays. Mr. Ross would like to include these as members of the camp if possible.

To board these girls during the period of the camp would cost $4.50 per head or a total of $112.50. Will it be possible for the Department to make a grant of this amount to assist in this very helpful work? The Round Lake School is practically a school for the Protestant Indian children of the Agency and naturally it has always been somewhat of a grievance amongst the Protestant Indians of this Agency that they would be told that there was no room for their children whilst there were some 15 to 20 children from other Agencies attending the school.

The children of both the Moose Mountain and Assiniboine Agencies have to travel by train to school in any case and it is practically the same to them whether they go to the Round Lake or Brandon School.

With regard to the children mentioned in your letter whilst there was no authority for these transfers the Revd. From the information given in your letter, the Department feels that these children should be considered Catholics. Toronto,
Ontario.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

It is more than a year ago that Mr. Alex Belanger asked me if he could put his children in Round Lake School. As Mr. Belanger is a Catholic, I referred him to the Indian Agent. The Agent later informed me he had received the request, that he had informed Mr. Belanger that he would require to sign an affidavit agreeing to have his children brought up in the Protestant faith and that he was giving him a good long time to consider the matter before giving him the opportunity even of taking that step.

At some time during the winter the affidavit was signed and forwarded to Ottawa for approval. The oldest child was sent to us by the mother about a month ago and has been here since. A recent letter from the Agent informs me that the Department has ordered that these children must attend a Catholic school.

A number of Indians gathered on Friday near the school to be with their children during the holiday and to take part in the communion service which was held here yesterday. With these Protestant Indians came Mrs. Belanger and she requested that I baptise her three months old child.

I asked as to her past. She informed me that she was born at Ramsack and had been baptised in her infancy by Rev. Mr. Mawhinney. She had received her education at File Hills school. She had joined the Catholic church when she married and had had her four children baptised by the priest. But as neither she nor her husband wished to have their children trained in a Catholic school, she had decided to come back to her own church.

When I told her what the Department ordered, she asked if she could have all her children baptised. So we baptised all five last night.

Her husband is at present serving a term in jail charged with non-support of his family.

On no occasion have I ever used any influence to induce these people to change their religion.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd.) R.J. Ross,

I feel that you will agree with me that it is in the best interests of all parties concerned to conform as closely as possible with the intention of the Indian Act, viz., that Catholic children should be assigned to schools conducted under Catholic auspices and Protestant children to schools conducted under Protestant auspices. Under these circumstances, Mr. Ostrander was informed that the Department was not prepared to approve of the admission of the Belanger children to the Round Lake Indian Residential School. Enclosed please find a declaration which has been forwarded by Mr. Alex. Belanger of Round Lake, who has been asking through the Indian Agent and the Principal of the School, Rev. H. J. Ross, that his children be permitted to receive their education in the school there.

I understand that the local Indian Agent has written you, supporting the desire of the father to have his children placed in our school. The application forms for admission have all been prepared and will go forward to you with the returns from the school.

Neither one of these children has ever attended either a Roman Catholic Day School or Residential School. It would appear, therefore, as if this is a case where the Department should acquiesce in the desire of the father and the recommendation of the Indian Agent on the ground.

I hope that you enjoyed your visit to Western Canada and shall look forward with great pleasure to seeing you in the near future.

Yours very sincerely,

KJB.M.T

Encl.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 6th instant, No. 108-1-10, in connection with the children of Alex Belanger, I beg to say that the Reverend Principal of the Round Lake Residential School has been keeping the two oldest of these children in his school since the holidays, although instructed by me, in my letter of the 4th April, to return them to their homes. On my next visit to the school, after these instructions were issued, I found the children still at the school and when I enquired into the matter the Principal informed me that his church authorities were making arrangements about them.

The Principal now informs me that he has had a communication from his church authorities to the effect that if the father joins the United Church it will be in order for the children to be sent to the Round Lake School. Belanger has not yet joined the United Church but has signed some kind of an acknowledgement which the Reverend Principal has forwarded to the Church authorities for further action. I have not seen this document.

I may say that Belanger is now out of goal, having recently completed his sentence, has been working for a white farmer near the reserve and assisting his family as far as possible from wages earned, but I am having some difficulty keeping the husband and wife from separating as the wife has now become stubborn and refuses to live with the husband any longer. They are still both determined to have the children admitted to the Round Lake School, if any.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B.Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

I understand that the principal of the Roman Catholic School called at the home of Mr. Alex. Belanger on at least two occasions to persuade Mr. Belanger to send his children to Crooked Lake School. Mr. Belanger refused on both occasions. He recently moved to a house within a quarter of a mile of Round Lake School. Last evening he was baptised and received into the membership of the United Church of Canada.

Some months ago the Department ruled that Mr. Belanger could not put his children in Round Lake School until he himself became a Protestant. He has now become an out and out Protestant; I do not see how they can refuse any longer to accede to the wishes of this Indian.

Yours truly,

(sgd.) R. J. Ross,

Mr. J. P. R. Ostrander
Broadview Sask.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Mr. Alex Belanger returned last night and recounted a conversation he had with the priest at Cowessess School. He told the priest that he and his family were Protestant and that his children would be Protestant when they left school if they were forced into his school. He asked that his children not be taught the Catholic Religion. In comparing the educational advantages of the two institutions he said you had only to see the children together to decide which was giving the better education. He instanced the case of a little girl named Tanner aged 13 years and whose father asked him to find out from her the time of day. She could not tell the time of day although she had been 6 years in school. When the priest hinted that influence had been brought to bear upon him to become Protestant, Mr. Belanger at once corrected him, and told him that since his boy was two years old he had been planning to have him educated at Round Lake.

Mr. Belanger says he intends to fight the case. He seems to have the sympathy of the Indians, even of the Catholic Indians. If the case goes to court, he will have the sympathy of the public. My own opinion is that he is right in his contention and that he will likely win out in the long run. I therefore strongly advise the Department to drop the case at this stage.

The case of the other Indians to whom you referred yesterday is entirely different. In fact, they have no case. My chief interest is in seeing that this Indian gets fair play.

Yours truly,

Signed. R. J. Ross.

Sir:—

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter received from the Revd. R. J. Ross, Principal of the Round Lake I. R. School with reference to the admission of a son of Louis Crowe of Kaskewistahaw Band to his school.

This case is very similar to that of the Alec Belanger children regarding which there has been a great deal of correspondence between the Department and this office and to which a definite ruling has been given that the children must not be admitted to the Round Lake School.

Since receiving this letter I have had a talk with Louis Crowe and he has furnished me with the following particulars.

He and his wife were both baptised as Catholics when babies. For some reason Louis was admitted to the Round Lake School where he received his education. His wife was educated at the Qu'Appelle I. R. School at Lebret. The child now in question was baptised as a Catholic at Lebret (the father states that this was against his wishes but that is beside the point). In conversation with Louis Crowe today he expressed a willingness to place the child in any other I. R. School but he strongly objects to placing him in the Cowessess I. R. School.

At the present time there seems to be a strong feeling amongst the Indians against the Revd. Fr. Chatelaine, Principal at that school and I think his refusal to allow the boy to be placed there is because of this feeling at the present time.

The boy is only 7 years old and I do not think that there is any need for him to be placed in school immediately but if the Revd. Fr. Leonard of the Qu'Appelle School is looking for recruits the boy could be sent there if the Department so desires.

Kindly instruct me in the matter.

Your obedient servant

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

Re Alex Belanger, Crooked Lake Agency, Sask.

The above party has consulted the writer in reference to the school situation relative to his children. Through correspondence with Mr. Ostreider, the Indian Agent, it appears that at the moment the children in question are not attending school, and of course this is unsatisfactory for all parties concerned.

As you are aware this man and his family are no longer Roman Catholic, in fact the wife never has been; they are all members of the United Church and have applied to have these children admitted to Round Lake School, but permission has been refused.

There appears to be some regulation to the effect that children shall go to the school of the church in which they are first baptized. This is hard to understand, and appears to be a direct contravention of the Indian Act, for under the provisions of such a Protestant child cannot be forced to attend a Roman Catholic school. The result in this case appears to be that the children are refused attendance at the school of their religion, and now are barred from an education.

From a legal angle it would appear as it would be possible to take the necessary action through the courts to force admission to Round Lake school, but surely there is some way whereby the matter can be arranged without going to this extremity. I may say however, that my client advises me that he positively refuses to have his children attend the Roman Catholic institution.

I shall be glad to hear from you at an early date.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I regret to inform you that Joseph Louison, a pupil of the Round Lake Residential School, was accidentally drowned in Round Lake on the 30th ultimo.

The Coroner was called to enquire into the accident and I was present at the enquiry. It was decided that the death was purely accidental and that no inquest was necessary. The facts were as follows:

The school is on the north side of the lake. On the 29th, the day before the accident, there was a high wind from the south, which carried a boat, belonging to Charles Assinaboine, Indian of Ochapowace Reserve, from the south to the north shore, near the school. That evening some of the school boys were seen playing with the boat and were ordered to stay away from it and they were again warned the morning of the 30th by the Reverend Principal. When the children were let out for recess at 3:00 P.M., three of them went down to the lake, unknown by any of the school staff. They commenced playing with the boat and the deceased boy was in the boat. There was a high wind from the north, which carried the boat away from shore with the boy in it. The other two boys tried to catch the boat, but it drifted out into deep water and they were unable to reach it. It continued to drift out and when it was about 200 feet from shore the boy became very frightened and jumped out of it into about eight feet of water. The boy could swim a little, but as the waves were high, he soon sank. The other two boys immediately ran to the school and informed the Reverend Principal and every effort was made to locate the body, but it took two hours and there was no life in the body when it was found.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of Norman and Reynold Belanger to the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

It is over a year since the Department first received a request for the admission of these children to the Round Lake School. Information received in the meantime indicates that the parents are now recognized as members of the United Church. Under these circumstances, the Department has no alternative but to allow the education of the children under Protestant auspices and the admission of Norman and Reynold Belanger to the Round Lake Indian Residential School is approved. The Department does not consider that this case should form a precedent as only those children can be admitted to the Round Lake School whose parents are recognized as Protestants.

The Principals of both schools in your agency should be urged to confine their recruiting activities to families who are recognized as members of their respective churches.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

He has a son named Lloyd aged 5 years which boy wishes to go to school with his sister.

I understand that Mr. Ross the principal will take this boy in the school if the Department approves although he is on the young side.

Herbert himself is a very fair Indian, quite intelligent and I feel that probably the early attendance of the child to school may be in this case of considerable advantage to the boy as he may develop into a really intelligent pupil.

If the Department would consider his application I would be pleased to be so advised in which case I would complete and submit form of application etc.

Your obedient servant

Sir,

I beg to advise that there is an Indian girl at the Round Lake Indian Residential School, Mary Taggart by name, who has an opportunity of going to Vancouver to take her Grade 3 and continue in her studies there until permitted to take up her duties in training for a nurse. She is an exception girl and the matron of the school has a married son in Vancouver who wants Mary to stay there with them during the time she is at school where she will have a home and proper supervision during the time she is attending classes. Mrs. Therian, the Matron of Round Lake School, who has been granted furlough for three months, proposes going to Vancouver and would take Mary along with her, provided arrangements can be made with the Department to permit Mary to go there and attend school as cited above. Dr. Therian and his wife have offered her a home and the church authorities have taken up the question of her admittance in training for a nurse with the Hospital authorities in Vancouver and received definite assurance that when she secures the required certificates, she will be admitted.

As there is considerable expense as to her books & clothes in attending a school in Vancouver, the school authorities here ask if she could be continued on their roll as a pupil of Round Lake School, when they would attend to her tuition and board themselves from here.

Mary has about $15. here at the office which would do for pin money en route, to Vancouver and asks that her treaty and interest be kept for her to draw upon while at school for her other requirements. Her parents have agreed to let her go. Mrs. Therian, the matron's son, Dr. Therian and wife, have agreed to give her a home with them while attending school, and now seek Department's permission with the continued grant to Round Lake school for Mary to send her there where she has an opportunity to make good. She has attained the age for leaving school and wants to go to Vancouver to finish and go into training for a nurse.
May I have Department permission to authorize this and if so as Mrs. Therian is leaving for Vancouver on June 29th, would I be authorized to issue her a free transportation requisition from Broadview to Vancouver.

For the extra clothing she would need in attending an outside school, Mrs. Therian states that the church are prepared to look after that and she herself personally will look after Mary's purchases.

As there is not very much time between now and the end of the month could I have this authority by wire so that Mary can get ready in time to go with Mrs. Therian.

All arrangements have been made by the church authorities for her tuition and board, the whole thing hinges on securing Department authority to permit the Round Lake School to continue her on their roll as a grant earning pupil, from which her tuition, books and board will be attended to.

She is an exceptional girl for an Indian and believe she warrants this opportunity of furthering her studies being granted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Eben A.W. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

So many difficulties might occur in the plan outlined in your letter if the girl went to Vancouver and did not prove satisfactory in two or three months and there would be considerable trouble in having her returned. I might say that this occurred at another residential school where a proposal similar to yours was approved by the Department.

Taking everything into consideration, the Department cannot approve the recommendation made by you.

Yours truly,

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

2. On receipt of the above information I patrolled to the Crooked Lake Agency and from there, accompanied by Bert Francis, a headman of the Cowessess Reserve, I continued the patrol to Crooked Lake and visited the homes of relatives of the boys and other Indian residences; it was believed the boys might have visited but no information concerning them was obtained. Ottawa, November 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Dr. Thomas Robertson, who recently visited your agency, has written with respect to an Indian girl - Mary Taypotat, who wishes to take a course in training as a nurse. He states she has a Grade II standing.

In this connection I would refer you to your letter dated June 15th, last, in which you stated that she wished to go to Vancouver, to take her Grade II and continue in her studies.

The Department understands Mary Taypotat is 17 years of age and is still a pupil at the Round Lake Indian Residential School. Has she sufficient educational standing to enter a hospital for a course in training? If so, you should communicate with the Department, after consultation with the Principal of the Round Lake School, and state the name of the hospital which this girl wishes to enter for her training. I would point out, however, that if any assistance is granted towards her expenses, uniforms, etc., the Department could accept no responsibility in arranging for her employment after she would complete her hospital training. I shall be pleased to hear from you at your early convenience, regarding the matter.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant it is rather difficult for us to decide whether or not Leita Pearl Thomas should be returned to the mother.

Such action would have the tendency of making the mother realize that she is at least partly responsible for the child's maintenance. However, if the home conditions are not suitable it would appear preferable to leave the girl in the Round Lake School. Whatever action you decide to take will meet with our approval.

In reference to the above, I beg to report that on the p.m. of this date, a telephone message was received from Father De Vereenens, Principal of the Indian School at Crooked Lake, to the effect that the above mentioned had that afternoon run away from the school, and would probably be at the home of Joe Still, Ochappawase Reserve, as the above mentioned had stated previously, that Still would take him home to Moose Mountains, White Bear Reserve if he wanted to go.

2. A patrol per Police Car was made to the home of Joe Still on Ochappawase Reserve, and on being questioned stated that he had only met the above mentioned on one occasion, when he was at the Mission about two weeks ago, and that he had not seen him since that time.

3. A further patrol was also made to the Farm Instructor's residence and Mr Russell advised with respect to the above, and owing to the lateness the patrol returned to Broadview, all Indians being in bed and no information at this time could be gained.

24-10-40
4. On the p.m. of this date, a further patrol was made to the home of William Smoker, Kahkewistinaw Reserve, this Indian being a Grandfather of the above mentioned, and it was thought that he might be there, but from enquiries made of Smoker he stated that he had not seen the boy for over a month, when he was at the Mission, and it was also thought by Smoker, that the boy would not go to him if he ran away, as he would return him to school.

5. Later while patrolling the Qu'Appelle valley on Cowessess Reserve, the above mentioned was met with and returned to the School.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sirs:

The Indians on Sakimay Reserve, Crooked Lake Agency in Saskatchewan request that their children be released at Christmas time from Round Lake Indian Residential School for the purpose of spending the Christmas vacation at home on the Reserve. I informed them this was a matter that rested with the Department and that likely there would be a ruling to govern their action toward all Residential schools, in this matter.

It would clear the air considerably with reference to this problem if you would for the benefit of all state what stand the department take toward permitting children to go home for the holiday at Christmas. Restriction in this regard seemingly is something new to this group of Indians, so much so that I fear they lay the blame for the exercise of discipline in this matter on what may be termed the enthusiasms of a New Principal.

Trusting we may receive from you at your earliest convenience the information that will result in making the above matter clear and satisfactory to all, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

FOR ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Ottawa,
September 29, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the principal of the Round Lake residential school in which he requests a definite ruling regarding the allowance of Christmas holidays to the pupils.

For the information of the Principals of the Indian residential schools in your Agency and yourself I enclose copies of the regulations covering the granting of holidays in Indian residential schools. For reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you the Department has always taken the position that the allowing of holidays during the winter season is neither in the best interests of the pupils themselves nor conducive to the progress of the residential schools. We would have no objection to the children going home for Christmas day only provided that they would return to the school the same evening. As a matter of fact it would be preferable for the schools to arrange some special celebration on either Christmas day or one of the days of Christmas week and have the parents come to the school and spend the day with their children.

Please advise the principal of the Round Lake residential school and the principal of the Cowessess residential school regarding our wishes in the above matter.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to Robert and Hazel Stevenson.

The Department presumes that the information given at the time these children were admitted to the Round Lake residential school was correct and under these circumstances they were eligible for admission to that school. We are not prepared to approve their admission to any other school at the present time.

You should arrange with the father to have them returned to the Round Lake school immediately. It is difficult to understand why the Principal allowed the father to take the children from the school. As you are aware when children are regularly admitted they should not be discharged without our approval.

Yours truly,

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re File No.108-1-10, July 21st, 1941.

Replying to your letter of the above date with further reference to the Applications for Admission to the Round Lake School for Dorseen and Kenneth Lequahquay. Though I have made several inquiries I can add very little to what I mentioned in my letter of July 14th.

Lequahquay is at present in the army. I interviewed Mrs. Lequahquay and while she admitted signing the declaration mentioned in our previous letter (copy of which is enclosed herewith) she stated that she had done so because Round Lake School was full at the time and as her husband was away she was unable to support her children. She signed the statement that she and her husband were Roman Catholics as this was the only way she could have them admitted to Cowessess School.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter from Lequahquay forwarded to me today by Mr. Huston. From this and from Mrs. Lequahquay's present attitude it would appear that it is the parents wishes that the children should be sent to Round Lake School.

I may add that I asked Lequahquay for a written statement but he evidently forwarded it to Mr. Huston instead of myself. I regret the delay in answering your letter but I was awaiting this statement.

Your obedient servant,

W.J.D. Kelley, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir-

My wife writes that the children have not been yet admitted to the school on account of Religion. I myself as a child was first admitted to the Crooked Lake School, but was transferred to the Round Lake school and I have never had any intention to let any of my own children enter into the Catholic School and it was certainly a big mistake that my wife made in letting my two little ones go there, of course she never had anything to do with Catholic religion or was never in their church or knew about their beliefs, so that I do not blame her for putting them there. When Rev. Ross told her that the Round Lake School was full, I was out working at the time and she must have run short of food, and I understand that Mr. Ostrander the Indian Agent would not help her at the time. She thought that one Industrial School was just the same as another, I had the experience of being in both schools so that I will go to any means in getting my little ones educated in the Round Lake school or any other but a Catholic school. My wife and I are both strong believers in the religion that Mr. H. McKay taught us and I am sure that Rev. Huston, you will do all you can to have my little ones educated in the school I attended.

Now that I am older and have the responsibility of looking after a family, I am sorry that I did not try to learn more when I had the chance so that I wish to give my children all the chance of learning that I can,

Respectfully yours,

Pte. Archie Mequakquay.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant the Department is prepared to approve the transfer of Henry Bear from the Round Lake Residential School to the Brandon Residential School. I note that this boy is past Grade 8 and presumably the mother wishes him to attend high school. It should be distinctly understood that in transferring him to Brandon the Department will only pay his per capita grant at that school. Any extra expenses that may be incurred in sending him to high school will have to be paid by the mother. These extra expenses will probably amount to $100.00 or more each academic year. I am so advising the Principal of the Brandon Residential School.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Huston:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to Bella McKay.

Our funds are so limited this year that it is found impossible to favourably consider allowing tuition grants for pupils who wish to attend high school for the first time. As you are probably aware, if this girl was transferred to the Brandon School in order to permit her to take high school work, there would be considerable additional expense, over and above your per capita allowance. This amount would increase as her education advanced. There is the additional fact that, even though Indian girls are given higher education, our experience shows that it is extremely difficult for them to obtain positions as a result of their educational qualifications. I regret that favourable consideration cannot be given to your application regarding Bella McKay, but I feel you will realize that she has been treated in the same manner as many other applicants throughout the Dominion.

Mrs. Ross has decided to teach in our Walpole Island Day School during the coming academic year. She was very successful at Moraviantown, and I feel certain that she will meet with equal success in her new school.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Your letter of August the twenty second was handed to me along with an accumulated amount of mail when I returned from my holidays last night. That will I trust explain my delay in reply.

Regarding your enquiry concerning Belle McKay #0217, we had hoped that she might be permitted to go to Brandon. She is the only one among all our graduates for whom we are making this request. We hope the Department will see fit to grant this favor. The only expense to the Department would be the amount of grant allowed the Indian Residential School at Brandon for each pupil in attendance. This girl I had hoped would be able to begin her studies when school opens to-morrow but due to my absence there has been considerable delay. Would you kindly give this matter your immediate attention. Our new address is Whitewood, Saskatchewan.

Mrs. R.J. Ross often spoke of you. Mr. Ross who retired three years ago died about two months ago. We hope sometime to have Mrs. Ross back on our staff. There are few teachers could compare with her when it came to transforming Indians. Trusting you too have had a good vacation. I remain,

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the application that has been made for the admission of Doreen Mequahquay and Kenneth Mequahquay to the Round Lake Indian Residential School.

In view of the information contained in your letter, the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of these children at the present time. Principals of residential schools have been repeatedly advised that children whose religious status is doubtful should not be accepted until all facts have been laid before the Department and our decision has been given. These two children should therefore be returned to their parents immediately. When this is done you should investigate the case fully and report to the Department.

In checking the June quarter return it is found that no application or certificate of health has been submitted for Ketha Francis, No. 0258. The necessary form for this girl should be submitted as soon as possible.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letters of the 29th ultimo and 13th instant, you may inform the Principal of the Round Lake Residential School that the admission of the following children is approved:

Ernest Whitequill          Lorne Sparvier
Eileen Watcheston          Beatrice Sparvier
Arnold Douglas Isaac

The discharge of pupil No. 189 is also approved.

From the information contained on the return, Grace Assiniboine, No. 0218, must be 17 years of age and Fernie Thomas, No. 195, is over 16. You are aware of the regulation which provides that when a pupil reaches 16 application should be made for discharge, or a request for permission to keep such pupil for a longer period should be forwarded. In the latter event, a definite reason should be given for desiring such action. Please consult the Principal regarding these two pupils and let me have a recommendation from you at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Re File 108-1-10, July 20th, 1942.

Replying to your above letter, I took this matter up with Rev. A.C. Huston and he advised me that No. 0218 Grace Assiniboine and No. 198 Fernie Thomas would not be coming back to school, and that he would ask for their discharge at the end of the present quarter.

I regret the delay in answering your letter, but Mr. Huston has only recently returned from his holidays.

Your obedient servant,

W.J.D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

Aug. 19th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Rev. A.C. Huston, Principal of the Round Lake Residential has requested the transfer of the following pupils to the Brandon Residential School.

0228 Hilda Sheshep, this girl has special aptitude for studies. Her home life is not ideal as her mother is dead and her father is somewhat irresponsible as far as the girl's welfare is concerned.

0221 Barbara Gaddie - exceptionally clever and should have an opportunity to continue her studies.

197 Harry Kaysaywaysemat - Good student, would like to qualify for the Youth training plan.

The above pupils are only 15 years of age and would greatly benefit by another year at school. Mr. Huston advises that the Principal of the Brandon Residential School is willing to accept these pupils if the Department approves of their transfer.

I would recommend his request for your consideration.

Your obedient servant,

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that Bert Francis of the Ochapowace Reserve, Crooked Lake Agency, who was in the Canadian Army, has moved to Regina and is discharged from the Army. He has taken a house in Regina where he intends to reside in future, having secured a position with the Imperial Oil Company.

A short time ago his daughter, Kathleen, was admitted to the Round Lake school. Bert now wants her discharged and to attend a day school in Regina. Personally, I see no objection to this, however, I shall await your decision in the matter.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
September 15, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant and to state that your recommendation that Kathleen Francis be discharged from the Round Lake Residential School is acceptable to the Department and approved. You might notify the Principal of the Round Lake School of this decision.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Mr. M. Christianson,
Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg.,
Saskatoon & Victoria,
Regina, Sask.

Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital  
Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.  
January 15, 1943

Re: Hazel Keguhtoowsy, Age 6,  
#154 Sakimay Res., Crooked Lake Agency.

Enclosed please find application for admission to the Round Lake Indian Residential School, for the above named Indian Child. This admission form has been forwarded to me by Indian Agent, W.J.D. Kerley, requesting that I complete the Medical examination and forward the original copy direct to Ottawa.

This Indian child was admitted to the Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital on December 21, 1941 with a minimum Pulmonary Lesion.

This little girl was living with her Grandparents at the time of her admission to hospital. Her Mother is dead and her Father has not remarried. Both the Grandparents are chronic spreaders. To return this child to that home is only going to expose her to mass re-infection. According to the information received from Mr. Kerley, there is accommodation at the Round Lake School. They already have their allotted number, therefore, no grant is available at present for this child.

This child will not benefit further from hospital care, she has reached the age when she will benefit by attending school. It would be folly to return her to her Grandparents home, which is just a hot bed for Tuberculous infection.

For the above reasons, I beg to recommend that the annual grant be paid to Round Lake School for this child, so that she may be admitted, thereby freeing a bed in the hospital, which is needed for other cases requiring immediate treatment.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

M.D.
Medical Superintendent
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir,

In reference to our conversation of Oct. 26 re. King Acoose and his son Ernest who is attending Cowessess School. I understand that King Acoose has been to P.C. Jeff of Greenfell to get him to write a letter to the Department about the boy being taken back to school in the spring time. Mr. King came by me and asked me to phone the Agent about getting her boy Ernest out of school to help with the thrashing as his father was unable to work on the thrashing gang due to boils on his elbow. I thought to let the Agency and I could not contact the Agent so I told Mr. Blanch the clerk what she wanted and he said he would tell the Agent as soon as he saw him. The next day the boy was home on the reserve and he did not show up at the thrashing outfit.

I had to go to Greenfell to get some welding done for the thrashing outfit.

Imagine several days after he was home and he was in town with his father and mother on a load of wood. I met the Agent who was there and he asked me where Raymond Acrose and Ernest Acrose were at—they both had to be returned to school. Raymond Acrose had come to town with me so I told the Agent that both boys were in town so he said he would take them back to school. The Agent said I want to see King Acrose about it so I went with him and found King Acrose and the Agent explained to him that the boy had to return to school.

King Acrose told the Agent that he needed the boy home to help him put up his hay. The Agent told him that his hay would have been up long before this.

King Acrose has about three or four loads of hay up, he has all the horse power he needs and more, his mower is in good repair and there is no reason for him not having his hay up in July. In the month of July he had his boy home from school and his two grown up sons also and there was no reason why he could not have put all his hay cut and stacked then. The trouble was he bought...
a car and they were to bury running around in it.

I got king enough clover seed in the spring of 1943 to sow ten acres and it turned out to be a good crop. After Regina Fair I got him to cut it and told him he could stack it after it had laid for a day, so he stacked it and that is as far as he gets there was two lovely weeks of buying weather at the time, but it just laid that in coils and up to two weeks ago it was still laying out there. I have not seen it lately as I have been busy with road work.

He has two big hay flats with about forty loads of hay in them. He has not touched and I asked him if he would let another Indian put it up on stores but he refused. He has his married son George from helping him manage the farm and they are in no season with the equipment they face that they could not be right up to date with their work.

Yours Truly,

H.C. Arps
Farmer's Protector
Saskatchewan

Re File 108-1-10, Oct. 14th, 1943.

Replying to your above letter I beg to say that the statements contained in the second paragraph of Mr. Neff's letter are not correct. King Acoose has eight horses and twenty head of cattle.

The boy Ernest has been in school seven years and is now in Grade 7. He is a fairly good pupil. I discussed this matter with the Reverend Principal of Cowessess School and we both feel that this boy is not essential at home as King Acoose has a married son living on the farm. If we gave permission to this boy we would have many similar requests on the same grounds.

He had the boy home during the two months of holidays and instead of putting up hay was driving around in their car. He has only a small stack of hay up but has plenty of straw and there is an abundance of hay on the reserve which can be purchased from the proceeds of his crop.

I am returning Mr. Neff's letter herewith and also a letter on the above matter from Mr. Ainger, Farm Instructor on the Sakimay Reserve.

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 10, 1943.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of October 8, with reference to the son of King Acoose of the Sakimay Band. For your information I may say that the statement Acoose made to you, namely, that he has 35 cattle and 15 horses, is incorrect, as this Indian only has 20 head of cattle and 8 horses.

We have carefully investigated Acoose's request to have his son discharged from the Round Lake Residential School. It appears that the boy is making reasonable progress at the school mentioned, as he has completed one grade each year, which is the average for any child. Reports that we have received indicate that Acoose does not need his son to help him, as an older, married son is now living at home. Taking everything into consideration the Department feels that it is in the best interests of Ernest Acoose to remain at the Round Lake Residential School and we are not prepared to grant his discharge at the present time.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Garnet C. Neff, B.A.,
Grenfell, Sask.

Four boys, Byearl Gopher, Charley Stevenson, Sam Bear,
and Clarence Taypotat, pupils of the Round Lake Residential
School, have been misbehaving in several ways the most
serious offence being going into the girls' dormitory.

solution would be to transfer the four boys to the Brandon
Residential School. I phoned the Principal of the Brandon

health and until the new Principal arrives he has left

your approval.

Ottawa, January 25, 1946.

Reverend Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return your December Quarterly Return. It is very important that your school have this Return properly prepared as the Per Capita Allowance is paid on the average attendance which is paid from the number of days pupils are in residence during the Quarter.

In reviewing your Return, we find that in some cases you have not requested as many days grant as you should have. I believe, that you have not carefully noted circular letter of December 29th, 1944, nor the notes on the preparation of the Return shown on the back page of the form.

I wish to direct your attention to the following specific cases:

1. No. 250 is stated to have been transferred to the Gordon's School. No grant is requested for this pupil nor is the date of transfer given. If she was transferred to the Gordon's School on October 1st, this is correct not to request grant but if she was in the school for any period during the December Quarter grant should be requested.

2. Pupil No. 258. Grant is requested for seventy days but there is no explanation in the column for remarks stating why she was not present during the full Quarter.

3. Pupil No. 265. If this boy was not in residence at all during the Quarter the Return is correct. If he was in residence for any period, grant should be requested for that period.
4. Pupil No. 273. Grant is requested for twenty-four days as he is stated to have been out of school for five weeks. If you refer to circular letter of December 29th, 1944, you will note that the Department allows grant for thirty days sick leave. Consequently, in this case if the boy was in residence for twenty-four days the school is entitled for grant of fifty-four days.

5. No. 0244. The name of this pupil was shown on the September Return and grant requested for her. The statement is made "Not in attendance". What is meant by this? Was she absent for the full Quarter?

6. No. 0248. What is stated above regarding pupil No. 250 also applies in this case.

7. No. 0255. What has been stated regarding pupil No. 273 also applies in this case.

8. No. 0259. The same case as No. 0255.

9. No. 0266. The Return states that she was in the classroom for twenty-one days and no grant is requested for her. Under the heading "Total number of days pupil in residence during the Quarter" is marked nil.

10. No. 0270. What has been stated regarding No. 0266 also applies in this case.

11. No. 0282. What has been stated regarding No. 0285 also applies in this case.

It is possible that you are entitled to grant for the full Quarter if the pupil was in attendance at the school for sixty-two days or more. You are entitled to ninety-two days grant when you take into consideration the thirty days grant allowed for sick leave.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J. Gard,
Principal,

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, November 24, 1947.

Dear Mr. Card:

You will recall the correspondence we had in late August with regard to the complaints made concerning the Round Lake Residential School.

We have had some correspondence with Premier Douglas concerning this and other matters. His most recent representation is that Allen Tappotat be re-admitted to your school. You will recall that in your letter of August 26 you stated that if this boy would return to school and remain to attend classes regularly, you would accept him again. Before giving the final decision in this case, the Department would appreciate hearing from you as to any further local developments which might have caused you to change your mind in this regard.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. James A. Card,
Principal,
Round Lake Indian Residential School,
Whitehead, Saskatchewan.

Copy sent to Mr. OBTRANDER and Mr. KIRLAY
Ottawa, December 8, 1947.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent,
Broadview, Saskatchewan.

Allen Taypotat - former pupil,
Round Lake Residential School.

We have had some correspondence with Premier Douglas concerning the re-admission of the above pupil to the Round Lake Residential School. The Reverend Mr. J. A. Card, Principal of the above Residential School, has now informed the Department as follows:

"Regarding the proposed re-admission of Allen Taypotat to this school I have consulted the Matron of the school and the day school teacher.

"My stand remains as stated in my letter of August. If Allen Taypotat will attend classes regularly and be amenable to discipline, we shall accept him again as a pupil. At the same time we dare not countenance breaches of discipline that prejudice the good conduct of the whole school.

"Since the pupils will be in their homes for Christmas and New Years holidays he should not re-enter school until January 4th."

In view of the above information, the Department approves the re-admission of Allen Taypotat to the Round Lake Residential School on January 4th.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Ralfaro & Training.
