AIR MAIL

19th April, 1949.

Rev. J.A. Card,
Principal,
Round Lake Indian Residential School,
Stockholm, Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Card:

We have received your telegram of April 16th, but as stated in my wire the information was too indefinite to make any decision. When we hear from Mr. Ostrander the matter will receive further consideration.

It is difficult for us to understand why there should be any disagreement in connection with Easter holidays. It has never been our practice to authorize Easter holidays at residential schools. It has always been understood that the pupils should remain in residential schools during the Easter session.

The only authorized holidays are the months of July and August and the Christmas holiday leave about which you are advised each year.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST
Chief, Education Division
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to the telegram which the Department received from Reverend J.A. Card, Principal of the Round Lake Indian Residential School, and Army Message, File 661-10 (B.1), dated April 19th, 1949, to me in connection with truancy of the children in the Round Lake School, and Mr. Card's recommendation that they be expelled, I have discussed the matter with Indian Superintendent W.J.D. Kerley, and certainly the expulsion of two boys will not correct our troubles at this school.

The story seems to be that an Indian of the Cowessess Band, John Stevenson, received permission from Mr. Card for his daughter to go home to the Cowessess Reserve for Easter. Upon hearing this, Herbert Sparvier, an Indian of the Kahkanistahaw Band, who had a boy, Crawford, 12 years old, and a younger boy, in the Round Lake School, made the request that he be permitted to take them home for Easter, and was refused. Crawford Sparvier has been truant several times, and, fairly recently, was one of several boys who broke into the pantry at the school and stole extracts, which is the reason for Mr. Card refusing to permit him to go home for Easter. Sparvier then took Crawford and his younger brother away from the school without permission of the Principal, following which Mr. Card apparently wired the Department, as he says, "to see where I stood".

Mr. Card does not have proper control in his school, as is quite evident by the fact that some of the boys were able to break into the pantry and steal extracts. He makes little attempt to keep control most of the time, and on the rare occasions when he does attempt control, he is not very successful. I am certainly not in favour of expulsion of the Sparvier boys, and I am also not in favour of transferring them to the Brandon School, which has been suggested by Mr. Kerley.

I have heard rumours that Mr. Card is slated for the Principalship of another Indian residential school when the Round Lake School folds up. I hope the Department will not permit this,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6334, file 661-10, part 3)
as his management at the Round Lake School indicates that he is entirely unsuited to such work.

J.B.B. Qstrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

It is apparent that more than one has had access to spirituous liquor while away. Some of these boys were among those who broke into the pantry some weeks ago and took four bottles of extract, 16 oz. size. One boy was in very bad condition and had to be carried up to the dormitory.

Our punishment does not seem to deter these lads from going across into the reserve where the supply of liquor seems to be.

Some action must be taken to remove this menace and if not successful a strict ban must be put against all visiting on the reserve.

Sgd. J.A. Card,
Principal,
Round Lake Indian Residential School.
ROUND LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

The Woman's Missionary Society
United Church of Canada

Rev. J.A. Card,
Principal

Whitewood,
Saskatchewan.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Supt. Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Further to my other letter.

After the Christmas Holidays we had a number of run-a-ways which brought about an investigation by Mr. Kerley with a member of the R.C.M.P. here in the school.

Among the run-a-ways were two boys of one Herbert Sparvier. This parent brought charges against the teacher who had administered punishment in a perfect manner. The children were given the support of the parents and directed to run away if punished.

This day I had good reason to punish the older boy and again he left the school and I suppose headed for home.

He has been somewhat of an agitator. He took part in breaking into our school pantry and taking four 16 oz. bottles of extracts. One of the group was blank out and had to be carried in to bed.

At Easter the parents were encouraged to come down to the school and visit the children, but not to take the pupils back home. The visiting hours were 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. and this for 4 days.

In spite of this privilege the mother took her school children home for the four days against my warning. Had I been sure of my authority in this matter I should have requested that they be barred from this school.

Now I shall refuse to accept this boy back again. His school will have to continue somewhere so far as I am concerned.

On one occasion when this boy had skipped out I went in bob sleigh to bring him back. The father threatened my life at that time. These people are thinking and agitating for day school which they are not ready for.

If you can give us any advice or direction in handling these situations, and especially the liquor problem, we should be grateful.

I am,

Respectfully yours,

Sgd. J.A. Card,
Principal,
Round Lake Indian Residential School.

Regina, May 12th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copies of two letters received from Reverend J.A. Card, Principal of the Round Lake Indian Residential School in connection with the truancy and misconduct of certain boys in his school, and referred to in Department Army Message to me dated April 19th, 1949.

I have no comment to make in connection with this other than that it is a rather clear indication that Mr. Card has little control over the children in his school. It is to be hoped that if this school is to continue in operation for the next term a more capable Principal will be placed in charge.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

To Mr. Philan:

1. Indian schools should use the non-alcoholic flavourings.
2. Principals should not pursue pupils outside the school premises. Some other officer should take over.
3. A register of punishments, corporal and other, should be maintained in all schools. It is useless to talk about punishments that were not recorded.
4. The Easter season should be spent in school with due regard for religious observances.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a report of an examination made of the books and records at the above school on June 12th, 1936.

The examination covers a period of one fiscal year dating from 1/4/35 to 31/3/36.

Bank Reconciliation - Statement #1

There are two bank accounts kept at this school, one being a Trust Account and the other the Savings. The two pass books from the Imperial Bank, Broadview, were on hand and written up to the end of March.

The Trust Account balance was $37.97 and the Savings $273.65. The outstanding cheques amounted to $310.95, leaving a net balance of 69 cents, which agrees with cash book.

Revenue in the Dr. cash book was compared to pass book entries and all cancelled cheques to the Cr. entries. Vouchers were attached to the cancelled cheques and these were compared to synoptic entries.

There has evidently been an improvement in analysing the vouchers as they all appeared to be in the correct column in synoptic.

A bank adjustment is made every month and the balance carried forward.

Receipts & Expenditures - Statement #2

This statement was prepared from an analysis of the monthly synoptic totals and shows the total receipts to be $13,282.27 for the year.

The revenue from farm $1742.52 is somewhat lower than last year owing to the poor crop, but the sale of six purebred cattle helped materially.

The revenue from other sources includes the night watchman, $280.00, prize money $583.25, and sale of candies etc. $127.60.

The expenditures were $13,282.58 and it will be seen that they are $3,000.00 over the per capita grant.

N. G. Allen, Esq.,
Representative of the Treasury,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Receipts & Expenditures (Cont'd.)

The salaries show a reduction from last year and also the food and fuel. The fuel is exceptionally low for a school of this size, but the wood was secured from the school land. The farm expenses have always been very high at this school owing to the Principal concentrating so much time and money on his herd of purebred cattle. While the prize money won at the several fairs is fairly large, it is questionable whether it will pay the expenses in freight, hired help, etc., which is necessary for the purpose.

The cost per day shows a decrease of $10.00, but the estimated revenue from farm was included in this amount. The cost of food this year shows a reduction of $42.00, but here again the cost "in kind" was included.

Owing to the Principal being away all week, I was not able to get all the information required, but the farm instructor advised that 12 cattle and 6 pigs were killed for use in the school.

The livestock consists of 86 cattle, with 24 milking, 19 pigs and 19 horses.

The crop last year produced 900 bus. Wheat, 1500 bus. Oats and 100 bus. Flax.

The farming operations consist of 350 acres under cultivation and with present prospects, the returns should be real good this year.

The books and records appear to be kept in very good condition at present, which is evidently an improvement over previous years.

The Principal has always concentrated his efforts to maintaining a large herd of purebred cattle and, in a school of this kind, it is very questionable whether this is a good policy.

As stated above, I was unable to discuss the several matters with the Principal, but the cash book and cheques were made available by Mrs. Ross.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of May 17th, in which you give a quotation from the Report of the travelling auditor relative to Round Lake Indian Residential School. I should like to raise the question of the relation of the auditors to the schools which are operated by the United Church, and I should like to know by what authority any auditor gives instructions to any principal as to how he is to manage the affairs of the school.

Of course, you and I have come into relation to this work quite recently, and it may be that I have not the situation quite clearly in mind. As I see it, we are operating these schools under an agreement entered into between the various Churches and the Department of Indian Affairs in 1910. I have before me a copy of the agreement—in blank of course—and I find that it was to be in effect from April 1st, 1911, for a term of five years. I cannot find in the office any information about its renewal or otherwise. You can, however, advise me what changes have taken place in this agreement.

I find that the Church entered into an agreement with the Superintendent General to do certain things which, in the main, can be stated as to support, maintain and educate in a manner satisfactory to the Superintendent a certain number of pupils. The agreement goes on to state the regulations that govern the admission of the pupils. It says that the school shall be conducted under such regulations as may from time to time be approved by the Superintendent General. The Church agrees to provide such sufficient number of teachers as may, in the opinion of the Superintendent General be necessary for its satisfactory conduct. It agrees to provide teachers and officers qualified to give the pupils religious instruction; to instruct in care of stock, farming, and a whole lot of other things that are laid down in paragraph 9.

The Church is also to supply the pupils of said school to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General with sufficient clothing, subsistence, etc. The Church undertakes to keep the pupils clean and free from vermin, and to keep and maintain the school buildings in a sanitary condition; also to make certain reports on the school as may from time to time be required.
The Church is to permit the Superintendent General, or any person or persons named by him, to inspect the said school buildings and premises.

That is practically the whole of the agreement from the side of the Church.

The Superintendent General agrees to pay a certain rate per annum per pupil; the number of pupils so to be paid for not to exceed a certain number. The Superintendent General also agrees to provide the pupils of the said school with medicine, school books, etc.

Now the position which we take is this: That the United Church having made a contract to educate a certain number of children at Round Lake Residential School, for which the Government pays a certain sum, we are under no obligation to render to the Department of Indian Affairs an account of how the money is spent, and we are practically coming to the place where we must ask the Department to confine the attention of its inspectors to their proper sphere—which is to discover whether the Church is living up to the agreement made to provide certain facilities for the education, moral and intellectual, of the children placed in its care. We are quite prepared to admit that the Department has the right to send in as many inspectors as it likes to see that the purpose for which the money is spent is realized; but the details of the method in which this is to be done, we cannot agree are subject to inspection or audit by the auditors of the Department.

I think that, if you will look into it, you will realize that the position which we are taking has very much to support it. I think the alternative would be that, if we are to be subject to audit, etc., then we shall have to take it that the agreement which has been made is null and void. The Department pays us a certain per capita allowance, and we are responsible for providing for the education of the children within that amount of money. If that is not enough, we have to supplement it. If the position which seems to be implied in the auditor's actions and orders were carried to its logical conclusion, then I think the Department would be responsible for any deficit in the operation of these schools. I do not think you can have it both ways.

I wish you would look into this whole matter rather carefully. Some time ago I think a representation was made and the Minister was to give a ruling. I do not know whether this has been done. I may say that if a ruling is given that the auditor has a right to give orders to the school principal, then we shall reserve to ourselves all the rights of protesting against this ruling, and at the same time of drawing the attention of the Minister to the fact that a regulation which is made to apply to one or more institutions must, of necessity, apply to all the institutions of all
Mr. R. A. Hoey-

the Churches that are operating these schools. I think I am quite within the mark in saying that, at the present time, there are schools in connection with some of the Churches where the principal refuses to allow the auditor to have anything to do with his books.

If you like to take time to think this over and see under what agreement we operate, I shall be glad if you will let me know, because there is no particular hurry; and it may be that during the summer months, when the Department perhaps is not as busy as it is at some other times, there would be opportunity to make this study, and then you and I can discuss it some time in August.

With best regards,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 26th ultimo in which you discuss very fully the attitude of the Board of Home Missions in respect to the Government audit of the Indian residential schools administered by the Board.

You are no doubt aware that the present audit system was in force when I entered the Department about three years ago. No change whatever in the procedure followed has taken place in the interval. I shall be glad, however, to go into the matter rather carefully just as soon as the time at my disposal enables me to do so.

The Treasury officials inform me that about two years ago the Minister assured Parliament that in view of the substantial grants paid by the Government to residential schools a careful audit of these institutions would be made by the Department from year to year. Dear Sir:

I beg to submit a report of an audit made at
the above School on October 25th and 26th, 1942. The
audit covered the period of forty-two (42) months, dating
from April 1, 1939, to September 30, 1942. Because of the
Principal's absence, this school was not audited during Mr.
Willis' last visit.

Bank Reconciliation.

The pass book from the Bank of Montreal,
Whitewood, Saskatchewan, showed a deficit of $325.83, as at
September 30, 1942, and there were outstanding cheques
amounting to $182.07. Cash on hand totalled $15.25, and
the net debit balance of $422.65 agreed with the Cash Book.

All paid cheques were examined and compared to
Cash Book entries. There were vouchers on file for the
expenditures, and these were compared to the synoptic entries.
Several changes were necessitated in the synoptic, as little
attempt had been made to apportion such costs as gasoline and
oil, or hardware. All revenue was deposited and small
cheques drawn for petty cash purchases. A careful petty cash
book is kept, and balanced each month, and all expenditures
are shown in the synoptic. Although there appeared to be
vouchers for many cash payments, the method of filing made it
almost impossible to check to individual expenditures. This
matter was discussed with the Principal, and he promised to
keep each month's petty cash vouchers together and filed in
sequence.

The total revenue for the period amounted to
$54,830.25, including per capita grant and bonus of $42,965.81.
Church grants amounted to $3,133.34, and farm revenue totalled
$6,742.14, chiefly from the sale of cattle. The present
Principal has discontinued the practice of exhibiting cattle
at fairs, and this source of revenue shows a great decrease.
However, the records show that most of the prize money obtained
in former years was eaten up in expenses.

Revenue from other sources amounted to
$1,988.96, of which $1,000.00 was in night-watchmen's grants.

The item 'Staff-Board' is refunded by certain members of the Staff in payment of their board.

The expenditures totalled $55,380.05, and are shown in detail in Statement #2. National Defence Tax is shown separately from salaries, and starting with September, 1942, the income tax payments are shown.

The cost of operation per day was $43.29, an increase of $3.29 per day, while the cost per child per year was $217.34, an increase of $23.22. Fuel and light costs were up by about $7.00 per month, while Buildings and Repairs show an increase of about $18.00 per month, but this item was almost negligible in the last period. The cost of house equipment shows an increase of about fifty (50%) percent per month, and the Farm and Garden show an increase of about $7.00 per month. Several newspapers of farm equipment were purchased, including a new tractor, binder, cultivator and set of harrows. The School car and the old tractor were traded in on the tractor, and, as a result, the tractor cost only $385.82 in cash. No School car is now operated. Transportation costs show an increase of about $15.00 per month. During this period two trucks and a car were purchased.

Extra labour costs are down by about $10.00 per month, and Miscellaneous is up by about $3.00. The bank charges totalled $105.76, and include exchange on Toronto cheques from the Church authorities and interest on overdrafts.

The cost of clothing per pupil per year was $15.64, which is lower by $9.45, while food costs at $37.50 show an increase of $2.63.

The average attendance was 72.8, a decrease of 2.2.

Because of the extreme length of the period, I have prepared Statement #1-4, to show the revenue and expenditures for each of the fiscal years of 1939-40, 1940-41 and 1941-42, as well as for the first six months of the 1942-43 year. The greatest fluctuations in revenue are noted in Church Grants and farm. The large sale of cattle in 1939-40 makes that year's revenue about three times as great as in the other years. The expenditures are about normal throughout the several years, with the transportation costs of 1939-40 being rather high.

Statement #2-4, was prepared to make comparison of the operation costs for the various years included in this period. The highest cost per day was during 1939-40, with the cost during the first half of the current fiscal year coming next. The highest cost per pupil per year was also 1939-40. This was the year in which a change of Principals was made, and part of the increase was likely due to the inexperience of the new Principal, and also to the necessity for repairs and improvements to the buildings.

The costs of clothing and food are about the same during the various years, except that the food costs are higher during the current year.

I was informed that the farm consists of about 2,000 acres, of which about 300 acres are cultivated. No grain is grown for...
is grown for the market, but is all fed on the farm, and made into flour. The livestock consists of about 70 head of cattle, of which all but two are registered Holsteins. There are two purebred Shorthorn heifers, and the Principal intends to gradually build up this breed, while cutting down on the Holstein. There are also 10 horses, 50 hogs, and 130 hens and turkeys. The farm supplies all the milk and butter and vegetables, as well as a large part of the meat.

The Principal advised that the liabilities, other than the overdraft at the Bank, amounted to about $650.00, all of which are current bills. The sum of $500.00 was received on October 1st, from the Church authorities, in payment of the per capita grant, and a Church grant of $500.00 is to come shortly. There are also a number of hogs nearly ready for market. The Principal expects to operate without undue difficulty.

The books were in very good condition, with the exceptions noted above.

The pass book from the Bank of Montreal,
Whitewood, gave a balance of $77.71 as at June 30, 1943.
The outstanding cheques totalled $22.00, and there was

All paid cheques were examined and checked to
the cash book entries. Vouchers were on file to cover the
expenditures and these were compared with the specific
entries. The allocation to supplies was $204, with
the exception of soaps and cleaners which were under
"Miscellaneous". I transferred these to "House Equipment".
All revenue is deposited and the principal pays small accounts
from his petty cash fund, which is re-inbursed monthly by
cheque. A petty cash book is kept and the items transferred
to the cash book each month.

Revenue and Expenditure (Statements #1 and #2)

The revenue for the period amounted to $11,760.93,
of which $5,592.05 was from the per capita grant as received
from the Women's Missionary Society in Toronto, and $2,000.00
from Church grants.

Farm revenue totalled $976.88, of which $451.88
was from the sale of hogs, and $415.00 from the sale of
cattle.

The nightwatchman grant amounted to $280.00 and
there was also a $5.00 refund.

The expenditures for the period amounted to
$11,207.61, at an average cost of $41.05 per day, which is
$2.24 lower than for the previous period. The cost of operation
per pupil per year works out at $196.62 which is $20.72 lower.

The cost of clothing was $10.93 per year - a
decrease of $4.71 per pupil. However, a good part of the
year's clothing was purchased during the latter part of the
previous audit period.

The food costs were $37.59 per pupil per year -
an increase of 9 cents.

The average attendance of pupils was 76 - an increase of 3.2 - a fact which aided in keeping the average costs down.

Fuel and light costs were at about double the monthly rate of the previous 42 month period, but are only slightly higher than for the fiscal year 1941-42.

Buildings and Repair at $296.59 were quite low, while House Equipment at $388.62 shows a considerable reduction.

Farm costs totalled $1,166.70, and are down for the whole, and also any portion of the preceding period. It will be noted that no feed was purchased during the period. A milking-strain Shorthorn bull and heifer (with calf) were purchased for $400.00 during the period, as well as a team of driving horses for $180.00. The remaining $104.04 of the livestock purchases were for hogs, poultry and bees.

Transportation costs at $411.75 show a large decrease. No school car is operated, but the school pays for the operation of the principal's private car.

Extra labor at $168.42 was also down.

Miscellaneous was kept quite low, and includes bank operating charges and interest on an overdraft.

General

The principal advised that the total acreage of the farm is about 2,000 acres, with about 300 being cultivated. No grain was sold during the period, but is fed to livestock. The livestock consists of approximately 75 head of cattle, of which about 14 are milking. The above are all purebred Holsteins with the exception of 5 Shorthorns. There are also 11 horses, about 60 hogs and 175 poultry.

The farm supplies the school with milk and butter, and most of the meat. The 1942 vegetable crop was very good, but because of inadequate storage facilities considerable losses were sustained. A new root cellar is under construction this summer.

The principal also advised that there were no liabilities at June 30th except for about $120.00 incurred during June.

The books and records were in good condition and up to date, and are audited annually for the Church authorities. Mr. Huston co-operated fully during the audit.

The pass book from the Bank of Montreal, Whitewood, showed a balance of
$673.09 as at June 30, 1944. Several outstanding cheques totalled $185.05
and cash on hand amounted to $1,428, leaving a net balance of $489.46 which
agreed with the cash book.

All cheques available were checked to the cash book, and the cash book
entries for the period for which there were no cheques, were checked to the
pass book. Vouchers were on file to cover the expenditures, and these were
compared with the synoptic entries. Allocation to the synoptic was good. All
revenue was deposited and petty cash reimbursed by cheques drawn on the bank
account. Cash expenditures were not large.

Revenue & Expenditure

A total revenue of $16,680.31 received during the year, of which
$11,614.50 was received from the Women's Missionary Society on account of the
per capita grant. Church grants totalled $2,000.00, and the night watchman
grant $300.00. Farm revenue amounted to $2,645.27, mostly from the sale of
cattle. Revenue from other sources amounted to $40.54.

General

The books and records were in good condition and up to date to July 31st. However, as the July cheques could not be located, the cut-off was made as at June 30th.

The farmer, Mr. Osborne, gave me the following information regarding farming operations:

The farm consists of approximately 2,000 acres of which about 300 are cultivated. The 1943 crop yielded about 700 bus. of wheat averaging 35 bus. per acre; 7000 bus. of oats averaging 85 bus. per acre; and 750 bus. of barley averaging 40 bus. per acre. The 1944 crop is also good with harvest operations under way at the time of the audit.

The livestock consists of approximately 70 head of cattle of which 20 are milch cows; 7 sows, and 24 pigs; 10 horses; and 300 poultry.

I was unable to obtain a list of staff members for the coming year. I was given to understand that the principal is being transferred to the Portage la Prairie Residential School. I submit herewith the report of an audit made at the above school on July 15, 1946, covering the period of 24 months ending June 30, 1946.

The school has been under 3 principals during the period, and because of the changes, some difficulty was encountered in making a balance over the period. The fact that cheques and vouchers were not filed in sequence also caused some difficulty.

Bank Reconciliation

The Pass Book from the Bank of Montreal, Whitewood showed a balance of $554.89 as at close of business June 30, 1946. The outstanding Cheques totalled $263.04 and cash on hand amounted to $57.25, leaving a balance of $329.10 which agreed with the cash book.

Paid cheques were examined for endorsements, admissibility, etc., checked to relating entries in Cash Book and audit stamped.

Vouchers were checked approximately 60% to cash book, those relating to Building and Repairs were checked 100%.

Receipts for petty cash disbursements for the months of July and August were not in evidence in numerous instances. However, a memo account of same was kept. A number of the major items were verified by visiting local vendors and checking the source of origin. This occurred during the absence of the Principal on vacation, and whilst he was in hospital.

Farming Activities

The figures as shown in the above statement, as relating to acreage and livestock, were supplied by the "Farm Manager" and can be assumed as reasonably correct.

No records are available to show the value of farm equipment or other assets at the date of audit.

Operating Costs and Staff

In analyzing these costs a slight decrease in per capita cost is noted. This is no doubt due to the increase in number of pupils attending school.

Changes in staff since last audit have taken place in the teacher and gardener positions, and a cook and assistant farmer have been added to the staff.

General

The deferred account with the T.Eaton Company Ltd., commented upon in the last report has now been absorbed in the costs and it is not proposed to renew same.

Owing to the absence of the Principal through illness, a few minor questions remain unanswered and at the request of Mr. Ostrander, the Regional Supervisor, Indian Affairs, Saskatchewan, it is proposed to conduct another audit in about two months time, when the principal will no doubt have resumed his duties, or another principal will have been appointed.

Buildings inspected need extensive repairs and decorations, this applies particularly to the main school building.

Certificate

I hereby certify that I have examined the books and records of the Indian Residential School, Round Lake, Saskatchewan, and with the exceptions noted above, the attached statements reflect the transactions of the School, according to the records and explanations given me.

FROM: W.E. Jackson,
Treasury Auditor.

RE: Round Lake Indian Residential School
Round Lake, Sask.

An audit of the records of the above school has recently been completed for the period 9 Aug. 49 to 31 Mar. 50.

(a) Bank Reconciliation

A certificate of the Bank of Montreal, Whitewood, Sask., was obtained and the cash balance as shown in the school synoptic was reconciled with this certificate as shown in Statement No. 1. Cash on hand was not counted but the Principal stated that he had on hand the balance as shown in the statement.

(b) Receipts

All receipts as shown in the cash synoptic were checked to the bank book. It was found that some receipts had been used to make payments without being deposited in the bank. The principal was shown how an imprest petty cash account should be maintained to take care of such payments. The amount listed in receipts under "Bazaar Receipts" is apparently derived from the sales of second hand clothing which has been donated to the school by the women's missionary society.

(c) Disbursements

All paid cheques were examined as to signature and endorsement and checked to the cash synoptic. Two cheques numbered 5 and 9 in the amounts of $9.49 and $7.90 respectively which were issued prior to 1945 are still outstanding. Also cheque No. 64 in the amount of $5.58 is still outstanding. It was suggested to the Principal that he should immediately contact the payee in these instances in an endeavour to trace the missing cheques. Cheque No. 64 or 1950 in the amount of $358.30 was not seen at the time of audit although it had been cashed. It has presumably been misfiled and the invoices regarding it were audited. It has been the practice here to issue unnumbered cheques of varying amounts for use as petty cash and not enter them in the cash synoptic but in a separate "Petty Cash Book". This has had the effect of confusing the cash synoptic and as has been previously stated the proper method of operating a petty cash advance has been explained to the Principal.
It was also noted that the sum of $25.00 is being paid yearly to the local Postmaster for a quarterly audit of the school books. This is unusual and would not appear to be necessary.

FARM ACTIVITIES

The information regarding farm activities is very meager due to the fact that the roads were impassable and it was impossible to contact the farm manager. This is explained further under the "General heading."

21 cattle died and a John Deere Tractor was burned as the result of a fire caused by the tractor back-firing while in the barn. This is a very serious loss as the cows supplied a great deal of milk for the school. It is understood that a new tractor is being purchased. The fire damage to the barn is reported by the Principal as not extensive.

OPERATIONAL COSTS

Statement No. 4 shows the comparison of operational costs for the last two fiscal years. The enormous increase in overall cost of operation per pupil would appear to be due to the large decrease in attendance and an increase in expenses. The addition of an engineer to the staff at a salary of $125.00 per month for the 1948-49 school period increases the salaries paid. This was explained by the Principal as necessary due to the poor condition of the heating and plumbing system in the school.

LIABILITIES

It was stated by the Principal that there are no outstanding liabilities in excess of the current monthly accounts, salaries, etc. There would appear to be sufficient funds on hand for these.

GENERAL

Due to the seasonal condition of the roads the audit was carried out in Whitewood. Mr. Card, the Principal, was not familiar with the various crop acreages and yields. Mr. Card reports that the school buildings are in very poor condition and a very definite fire hazard.

Owing to his physical condition Mr. Card has resigned, such resignation to take effect at the end of the school term. He has requested that another audit be made immediately prior to his leaving. The continued illness of the Principal would account for the errors and omissions found in the accounting system.
CERTIFICATE

I hereby certify that I have examined the accounts and records of the Round Lake Indian Residential School, Round Lake, Saskatchewan, for the period 9 Aug. 49 to 31 Mar. 50, and with any exceptions noted above, the attached statements reflect the transactions of the School, according to the records and the explanations given me.

E. Jackson,
Treasury Auditor.

We, the undersigned, Indians of Hesquahs River, Billy Agency, beg leave to send you this petition for a Boarding School in our Reserve.

Our reasons for asking are as follows:

We have over 30 children of school age in this reserve, and of this number there are about 24 whose parents are very anxious to comply with the Government's wishes by giving them a good education.

On Cole and Key Reserves there are 8 children who are enrolled and who are intended by their parents to be sent to a Catholic school, but without a boarding school, it is impossible for most of these children to have any education, the majority being too far to attend the day school regularly.

We could send our children to Opi Offella, but it is too far and anyone who knows the Indians is perfectly aware of their weak constitution. Of all the children we have sent to the Opi Offella Industrial School, but two are living, all the others died there or came back to die on the Reserve.

With this prospect before us, it is hard to expect us to send our young children so far away, as in all probability many of them would go there and die without the comfort of both parents and relatives.

On the other hand, we are quite prepared to send them there to complete their education when they are strong enough and advanced in age and learning.

The Secretary:

With reference to the request of His Grace Archbishop Langevin for a grant for 10 boarders for a Roman Catholic boarding school at Fort Pelly (St. Phillip's) I beg to say that applications have been made for the establishment and recognition of this school, which has been built near the Keeseekoose reserve, since May 1899 when Rev. Father DeCorby, missionary at Ft. Pelly forwarded a request to the Rt. Hon. the Premier for permission to build a boarding school on Keeseekoose reserve. This application was not favorably entertained and in June of that year the Premier was advised, in reply to a further communication addressed to him by Father DeCorby, that the Department did not consider it necessary that a boarding school should be established at this point.

His Grace Archbishop Langevin again brought this matter to the attention of the Department in 1901 when the Minister approved of the action already taken by the Deputy Superintendent General and directed that His Grace should be so informed and advised of the reasons as to why it was not considered expedient to accede thereto, which was chiefly on the ground that there were not enough children on the reserve to justify its establishment. His Grace renewed his application on the 6th March 1902 and on the 29th of that month he was informed...
that the Department had not sufficient information to enable it to arrive at a decision before the supplementary estimates would be submitted to Parliament, but that steps would be taken to officially enquire into the educational needs of these Indians. The Indian Commissioner, who was directed to make the necessary enquiries reported on the 30th ultimo, that after consulting with Mr McKenzie, who has charge of the Pelly Agency, he is of opinion that the recognition of a boarding school at this place might be postponed for a year or two as the Agent informed him that not a few of the Indian children are diseased and could not pass the necessary medical examination, there not being more than ten on the Reserve sufficiently healthy to be taken into such a school.

On the 4th instant the Commissioner was advised that the Department approved of his recommendation that the recognition of this school be postponed.

The Archbishop's statement that there are thirty children regularly going to school is not borne out by the Agent's report. The Roman Catholics have a day school on Keesekhouse reserve which is not well attended at present although some years ago it was in a prosperous condition. It is not the Department's fault that it has been allowed to run down and I think that if the missionary was as anxious to keep up the day school as he is to obtain recognition for the boarding school, much better results would follow.

There is no use disguising the fact that it is more in the interests of religious bodies carrying on mission work among the Indians to extend...
the boarding school system at the expense of the day school. The Indian in this district are chiefly hunters and their children will have to follow the same pursuit, and as I have frequently pointed out life in a boarding school is not the best means of fitting them to follow the chase.

I am of opinion that Indian education should be adapted to the mode of life of the Indians. They can obtain the rudiments of an English education at day schools, which is all the nomadic Indians will ever require. Boarding schools are best suited to the needs of Indians who are likely to take up farming and follow the white mode of life, while Industrial schools should only be for such Indians as are likely to come into closer contact with the whites.

The Department has knowledge that a building has been put up with the intention of carrying on a boarding school, but no encouragement was ever held out to the Church authorities that they would be recouped for the building or furnished a grant for the maintenance of pupils. In fact they were not allowed to put up their building on the reserve. A protest was received from Rev. Dr. Baird, of the Presbyterian Missionary Society against the recognition of this school, as a boarding school is conducted by that Society at Crowstand in this neighborhood. The only weight that could be attached to this protest was that there was no possible need of a second school there for the Roman Catholics.

Limiting their request to a grant for ten pupils, as I take it for six years, is only another way for inserting the thin edge of the wedge as past experience shows that if a school is once recognized
there is practically no limit to further demands.

The Archbishop's postscript that the local Agent and the Indian Commissioner are both in favor of this school is not borne out by the Commissioner's report above referred to.

Ottawa, August 12, 1913.

Memorandum for the Deputy Minister,

The Keesekoush Indian Boarding School is erected on property owned by the Oblates Order, the main building is built of logs, apparently erected at three different times, having also two small frame extensions in the rear.

The building is warmly constructed but has very low ceilings and provides accommodation for fifteen pupils only, while having floor accommodation for nearly three times that number, yet, owing to the nature of the construction, the present building cannot be altered to accommodate a greater number economically.

At the time of my inspection, the school authorities were very anxious to maintain the school and as the condition of their finances was such that they could not then erect a new building, this could only be done by utilizing the old building to its fullest extent for the requirements which had no fixed standard for floor and air space, and
erecting a wing providing class-room, dormitories for boys, offices, principal's quarters, heating plant for entire building, boys' recreation-room, shower baths for boys and girls, and a large dining room. The old building was divided so as to provide the other accommodation necessary, including a fully equipped isolation infirmary, with nurse's room and ward for boys and girls with separate entrance from outside thereto.

The new portion of the building is designed as a boys' wing for what will ultimately be a complete building, the old portion only remaining in use until it was possible to finish the balance of the new building required, as the present building is not expected to remain in condition longer than five years at most.

This method of extension is not, however, an economical one if the building is to be erected and owned by the Department, as the adapting of the old building for school use is a temporary expedient only, and an entirely new building will prove less expensive in cost of erection and maintenance.

The plan of the buildings prepared and sent to the school authorities was of a preliminary character only as it appears that early in 1912 the Department contemplated the establishing of an Indian day school in the vicinity of the Keeseekoose school on the Key's Band reserve which
it was feared would interfere with their chances of recruiting a sufficient number of pupils for this school when the plans were sent to the Rev. Father Magnan; this was called to his attention; but so far as I have been able to determine no further information respecting this is on file.

I would, therefore, recommend that providing a sufficient number of pupils can be recruited to establish and maintain this school, and it is decided to proceed with this as a departmental owned school that an entirely new building be erected.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have not the slightest doubt that the Church would be quite willing to reopen the School, and use the existing building for the time being; but sooner or later, the Department or the Church will be called upon to erect suitable buildings to carry on the work. Perhaps the Department would see fit to put an amount in the Estimates this year for the purpose of erecting a school to accommodate from 50 to 60 children; and if not to erect a school, place an amount for the maintenance of so many children in the existing building.

Mr. Scott:

The subject matter of the communications from Father Beys and Commissioner Graham was discussed by the Reverend Fathers Guy and Boyer at the time of their visit to the Department yesterday.

The situation, in brief, is as follows: The 1915 census shows that on the Leeseekouchee, Kay and Valley River reserves the Roman Catholics have a following of 132, as compared with 89 adherents to all other denominations. The Day School has been more or less of a failure: an average attendance of only 7 obtained. There are 52 children of school age, and the Reverend Father Beys is asking for the erection of a residential school to accommodate that number.

The old building, which in the event of a new school being erected could be used as a residence for the staff and storehouse, would be given to the Department of Indian Affairs in addition to perhaps 40 acres of land. I am convinced that if we asked for the whole of the quarter section that belongs to the Oblate Fathers and which is contiguous to our reserve, our request would be granted.

Mr. Commissioner Graham is in favour of a boarding school at this point or the reopening of the old building, with a view to ascertaining whether the Church would at this time make a success of a residential school at this point.

I personally believe that the Oblate Fathers would rather not try to carry on their activities in the old building, as it was a matter of accommodation that discouraged them some years ago. If we cannot afford to build on the Leeseekouchee reserve this next fiscal year, I believe that Father Beys and his staff would rather postpone commencing operations until such time as we can finance the project.

In the meantime, Sir, I will give this request due consideration in connection with the papers from the Reverend Father Guy, that you handed to me yesterday.

Dear Sir:

Mr. C. A. Bradbrooke, Indian Agent,
Pelby Agency, called on me yesterday in
regard to the report made by School
Inspector, Mr. Arthur D. Merrill, against
Mr. J. Inglett, as not being qualified to
teach in the St. Philips Indian School.

Mr. Merrill says in his report that
there is no progress. How can he know it,
for he was coming for the first time?

The word "progress" fore-supposes two
points of comparison. How can he form a
judgment, if he sees only one side of the
question, unless he wishes to imitate the
hunter, pointing his gun, without taking

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6334, file 662-1, part 1)
any aim? Moreover, how can Mr. Herrill substantiate his statement that there is no progress, for the most of the pupils arrived at school when the inspection was over?

Mr. Herrill started his inspection at nine o'clock. As the children come from a distance, they generally arrive at nine-thirty, or ten o'clock, when the weather is bad. Therefore, he found in the class-room only seven pupils, of whom three were white children, and the new teacher, Mrs. Inglett, not yet dressed for her class.

Had Inspector Herrill come at ten o'clock, he would have found twelve children, Indian children; fifteen including the three white children, and the teacher, in proper attire.

He would then have made a more complete and satisfactory inspection.

I was present myself at the inspection.
and I am glad to state that the three white children passed a good, interesting examination, and could compare favorably with any other pupils of their age in the public schools. Mr. Merrill should at least have given credit for them, or does he belong to that class of men who see everything black in Catholic schools?

I may say that I have had some twenty-five years experience in Indian schools, and I can certify that the Indian pupils, who were instructed by Mr. Merrill, showed as much proficiency as those in other Indian schools. This Indian school may be the first one Mr. Merrill has visited.

Another point to consider is that this school has been closed for months at a time, giving these children less chance than other children to make a good showing. Comparing their advancement
today, to what it was three months ago, their progress is evident and proves much in favor of their attendance at school and the efficiency of their former teacher, Miss De Reich.

But even if there was no progress, as stated in the Inspector's report, Mr. Merrill should not throw the blame on Mr. Ingloft.

Mr. Ingloft was appointed by the Indian Department as teacher to begin his duties, as such, at the beginning of this quarter. After Miss Reich left St. Philips on the 24th of September and, through kindness, Mr. Ingloft finished out her term, beginning to teach on the 25th of September, two days before the inspection. No wonder he was not prepared for a complete and advantageous examination of his pupils. He hardly knew their names, nor their standing in the school. Mr. Merrill was
informed of this fact, and, for that reason, his indulgence was requested.

However, Mr. Kerrill had the boldness to use a convenient word, to make a report against Mr. Biglopp, stating he was not qualified to teach in the St. Philips Indian School, and suggesting his dismissal.

An explanation of Mr. Kerrill's lack of judgment, common justice, and of his faulty reasoning, could not be found in the deep dissertations of Aristotle's philosophy.

Was it because, since Mr. Reich being a Protestant, he wanted to cover him with his paternal cloak, preferring to throw whatever blame there was, on Mr. Biglopp, who is of the Catholic faith, belonging to that faith, which makes him a ready mark for unfairness and injustice?

If this is so, Mr. Kerrill is certainly...
teaching in the most elementary qualifications required for an instructor, unless one must infer he is afflicted with a sudden aberration of mind, a thing to be regretted, but not to be condoned.

I am strongly protesting against this stupid, senseless report, apt to hurt and injure a first class teacher, who is, probably, more informed on educational matters than his superior himself, as proof of which, I refer you to the enclosed two copies: references of his qualifications.

Moreover, Mr. Ingloff, in 1912, was teaching the Latinization class, in the Jesuit College, in Malta. Therefore, there is no question about his qualification for teaching in an Indian school. He is fully competent to be a Professor in any school or University, where he would find a ready admission, had he in view, a good salary, and the comforts of life.
Inspired by a high ideal devotedness,
and self-denial, he prefers teaching in
Indian schools, at a poor salary, with
all the attending discomforts of teaching
in a poor Indian school.

The Indian Department should be
proud to count such a man on the staff
of teachers in Indian schools, and should
certainly encourage him, by appreciating
his worth.

It is a duty for me to rehabilitate
his reputation before the Indian Depart-
ment against the unjust accusation
made by Mr. Herrick, who was lacking
in justice even common sense, or he
would have suspended his judgment
until his second inspection.

I beg, at least, that you advise
Mr. Herrick to make an apology for
his unfounded accusation against
Mr. Inglett; otherwise, I would be forced
to have recourse to the public press.

I also desire that the St. Philips Indian school be inspected by another School Inspector than Mr. Kerrill.

I have given many proofs that I have very much at heart the education of the Indian children, and will always be pleased to receive any advice or suggestion benefitting the schools under my care; but I would be disheartened to have the St. Philips school inspected by such an unfair partial and so evidently ill disposed a man as Mr. Kerrill has shown himself to be.

Trusting in the fair play, and sense of justice of the high officers of the Indian Department, regardless of creed or race,

I am, Most Respectfully,

S. Perreault, O.M.D.

Dear Sir:

Below is a copy of a letter I have just sent to Duncan Scott Esq.

As I understand that the position of teacher of the Keese-Koose Indian Day School is now vacant, I hereby forward my application for the position.

I have been in pretty close touch with these Indians for many years, and have always taken a deep interest in their welfare, and I understand their nature pretty well.

With regard to my character etc., I could refer you to the Provincial or almost any of the Presidents of the Blake Order of St. Boniface.

As to my qualifications, I was born and educated at Manchester, England. I am enclosing three or four certificates that happen to still possess for your inspection. One is a "Second Class" College of Preceptors Certificate in which I passed in the highest Division.

I am enclosing the examination papers for the certificates enclosed in order to give you a better idea of the standing of these certificates.

In the Science and Arts examinations I had five certificates, but at the present time I can only find three of them. The subjects were: Pure Mathematics; Magnetism & Electricity; Inorganic Chemistry; Practical Plane & Solid Geometry; and Free-hand drawing.
ST. PHILIPS, Sask., Dec 23rd 1923.

I enclose three of these certificates, but all the examination papers.

While these qualifications seem pretty old, I might add, that I have been very much interested in education for many years. I have been secretary-treasurer of two Public School Districts for the last twelve years and three years respectively. And have had practically most of the management of them, as all the trustees are foreigners and very illiterate.

And I am enough interested in Education, to have paid my own expenses as delegate attending School Conventions for the last few years, as our trustees would not pay for their delegates.

As I intended at one time to secure a Teachers Certificate, I did a certain amount of studying on the methods of teaching, but finding the profession was overcrowded at that time, gave up the idea. I will be very much obliged if you will kindly return the enclosed certificates and Examination Papers under registered mail. And an early reply to my application will be greatly appreciated, in order to give me time to make my plans, if my application should be accepted.

Yours very truly,

George Barton.

Sir,

I wish to draw your attention to the condition of the Keesekoose Indian Day School. This building is rented from the Roman Catholic Church and is situated just off the Keesekoose Reserve, which condition means that the children have to come long distances, which in bad weather is a hardship, as they have to travel on foot or otherwise as best they can.

The School itself has long past its useful-ness, as it is badly lighted and heated and no proper ventilation, the ceiling is low, and there is not the cubic space of air necessary that there should be to keep children in good health and mental alertness while studying.

The place looks patched and dilapidated, the Indians are anxious to have a School centrally situated on the Reserve, and am of opinion that this course would be of benefit to all concerned.

The number of children of school age on this reserve is about 35 and there would be better control in getting a fuller attendance with a school on the reserve than there is at present, with the school situated where it is.

I therefore beg your consideration in this matter, as the conditions are such that this school has outlived its usefulness and is now on the score of health alone, unfit to use.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir,

All the Indians of this Keeseekoose Reserve are well aware of your deep interest and solicitude for their welfare. They therefore apply to you for a Boarding School for this Reserve and the surrounding Reserves.

The school should be built close to the present buildings of St. Philips Roman Catholic Mission.

There are a great many children left without any education, especially on Key Reserve, Valley River and Shoal River.

The necessity of this school has been recognised and approved the year before last by a vote of Parliament. The building however of this school was postponed for a more pressing one.

We beg to state that the necessity of a boarding school here is very urgent, and we hope that you will take immediate steps so that this school may be built next summer and our many children receive a proper education.

We on our part will do our best so that the school will prove a success in every way. We would willingly grant on our Reserve all the land necessary for the buildings and management of the school. In fact we have all signed our names on a petition to show that we are of the same mind as our chief in this matter, which petition is attached to this letter.

CONSTRUCTION OF A RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL AT ST. PHILIP'S, SASK.

It has been the matter of serious thought on the part of Oblate Missionaries authorities for the last few years to provide for adequate educational facilities for a large number of Indian children, living on KeeseeKouse, Côté, Key, Valley River, Nut Lake, Birch River, Swan River, Pelican Reserves and others.

A residential school has been already in full activity at St. Philip's but has been replaced by a temporary Day School for reasons known to the Department. After a careful survey of the situation and in consideration of repeated requests from the Indians, we have come to the conclusion that the erection at St. Philip's, Sask., of a modern building to accommodate about 100 children has become a necessity of such an importance that we do not hesitate to place the request for the construction of said building as the very first item on our list of major needs in view of the Estimates.

Commissioner Graham has discussed the situation thoroughly with Very Rev. Beys, O.M.I., and has reached the same conclusion as the latter, viz: The immediate necessity of the erection of a Residential School at St. Philip's.

Of course, we are aware that some of the above mentioned reserves are nearer certain other schools if a straight line is drawn but in reality we deem that it is only at St. Philip's that railway accommodation is most convenient and recruiting work possible.

In the course of my last visit West Very Rev. Fr Beys and myself met the Catholic Indians of KeeseeKouse and Côté Reserves who made to us a very strong request and offered to surrender a half section of land on the KeeseeKouse Reserve for the proposed school. Herewith annexed please find copy of petitions from the Indians of KeeseeKouse, Côté and Valley River Reserves, to build a residential school at St. Philip's.

The matter of the site might be a source of discussion but I take the liberty of expressing the Oblate Missionaries' opinion in the matter without prejudice to the decision of the Department.
St. Philips Sash.

Dear Sir,

I would like to get permission to make a change in the vacations of the St. Philips Indian Day School on Keeseekoose Reserve. For about the last three years the vacations at this school have been taken in Jan. and February. I would much prefer to divide the study time up a little better, by taking January, (the coldest month), and August, the hottest months. Two months at one time seem rather long for children to be away from school, and they are likely to forget a great deal. And it is a pretty long grind from the beginning of March until Rinas, through all the hot harvest weather, for both children and teacher.

All the schools around here, including the Otoe Indian school, have vacations in August. The teachers can get away in summer for a rest far better, and most children are wanted, and are kept home for help during the harvest in August anyhow.

I have always had a good attendance in December and March here, and I am pretty sure I would also have in February if the school was open.

I think my suggestion is well worthy of your approval. In fact it was only on account of one teacher here 3 or 4 years ago, that the present system was adopted. The teachers following since, though no liking it, thought it had always been that way here, and said nothing.

If the change of vacations from January and February to January and August, meets with your approval, and I feel sure it will, perhaps you will be kind enough to let me know as soon as possible, so I can then notify the children before they leave for Rinas.

Yours very respectfully,

George Barton - Teacher.

Dear Sir:

As the teacher of the Philip's Indian Day School at Messickhouse Reserve-Pelly Agency, I beg to bring to your notice a few facts, of which perhaps you are unaware, and of which I respectfully beg your favorable consideration.

This is one of the very few day schools that provide the children with a full hot meal at noon. This naturally entails considerable extra work, and in fact in some of the other day schools that do likewise, a special nation is engaged, and the teacher has only to attend to the teaching.

The children here get hot meat and vegetable soups, bread, rice, beans, jam, biscuits, and tea sugar, and milk, and sometimes eggs in summertime. The vegetables I provide—potatoes, carrots, onions, and turnips—by putting in a good school garden, which provides enough for the whole year. Milk, jam, and eggs I also provide free myself. The rest is provided by the Department.

Now a great deal of this cooking has necessarily to be done by my wife during school hours, and takes up an hour or two every morning, besides baking bread twice a week for the school. Then although I am with the children during the dinner and washing up, she comes and watches them while I eat my dinner, so they are never alone.

You see we are doing our very best to conduct this school in the way such a school should be run. At the same time the salary for all this work is very small. We would therefore like to ask you if you could not see your way to allow my wife a small allowance of say $10 per month for the burdens which she is obliged to do for this school, and which she has done now for over two years.

If you can see your way to assist us in this, and which I think you will agree is not asking too much of the Department, I assure you we will be very grateful indeed.

Yours very respectfully,

George Watson (teacher)

Dear Sir:

This year, in the immense territory of which I have charge, only one small school is to be built, the one of St Philips, near Kamsack, Sask.

Recently an increase in the grant has been attributed to some schools. In union with the four Bishops of my territory as well as their advisors and mine, I want to express that public moneys would be better used in building schools or enlarging the present ones, so as to give an opportunity to every Indian child to receive an education. The schools were going on and I am not aware that the cost of living has increased lately. Instead if the sane part of the population of Canada were acquainted with conditions in many reserves where all children are left in absolute material and mental neglect, a cry of protest would rise from one end of the Dominion to the other.

I am very anxious that the little granted to us be executed as early as possible so as to have some possibility to gather up the children next fall. I expected the tenders for our school to come out with those for the Sturgeon Landing School.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

It has been reported to me several times of late that it is the intention of the Government to build a rather expensive Indian Boarding School on the Kesekoose Reserve five miles north of the present Cote Improved Day School on the Cote Reserve. In connection with this I would like very respectfully to call your attention to the following considerations which may not have come under your notice:

1. There was a boarding school at or near the same location several years ago, which was closed owing largely to a lack of sympathetic support from the Indians. Later a day school was started in the same buildings.

2. There are only about ten Roman Catholic families on this Reserve and in order to get any considerable number of pupils from the neighboring reserves an effort may be made to recruit from Protestant families. This would naturally lead to friction and difficulties for Departmental officials.

3. If, as is stated it is the intention to draw a large number of pupils from other Reserves a hundred or more miles away, would it not be better to build the school nearer those Reserves from which most of the recruits would naturally come?

4. The Cote Day School has been serving the educational needs of the great majority of the Cote Indians for the past ten years, but as you may readily suppose there are some who would like to be set free from the responsibility of caring for their children and these have been talking of petitioning the Government to replace the present Cote Day School with a boarding school. I do not think such action is necessary at the present time but the grounds for the request are as good as in the case of the proposed school on the Kesekoose Reserve. But if that School is erected then the situation is changed and it may become very desirable from our point of view.

You will see therefore the complications that this proposed building would lead to and quite unnecessarily. The needs of the Kesekoose people could very well be served at a fraction of the expense by the erection of a day school in a central position. Such a school could be so located that only one family would have more than two miles to come to school.

In conclusion, let me say, that I write you in confidence that this matter will receive your careful consideration and that you will try to do what is best for all concerned.

I Am,

Yours Very Respectfully,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your letter of August 3rd. to hand and note what you say in regard to increased accommodation at the Cote School.

I would like again to repeat what I said before that I have no wish whatever to build up a boarding school at this point. No one would be better pleased than myself to find that there was no necessity for such a step, because I am fully aware of other problems which would be raised thereby. But as I said before the conditions which have given rise to this request have been brought about by the Indian Department erecting the St. Phillips School in such close proximity to the Cote School and where there was no real necessity for such action. I am told that we can send our pupils who cannot attend the Day School to File Hills or Brandon. Why did not the Department tell the Keesecoose R.C. people to send their children to Lebret or some other R.C. boarding school? They have less pupils who cannot attend a day school than we have. If this had been done two years ago, many thousands of Government money would have been saved and the present problem which is troubling us would not have arisen.

You assure me that our Protestant children cannot enter the St. Phillips School because the Department would not allow it. I know this is an old principle but you must know that it exists more in theory than in practice. A year ago two Protestant girls were taken into the St. Phillips School. I protested against it. The parents insisted on keeping them there where they could see them at any time. I brought the matter to the attention of Mr. Russell Ferrier when he was here a year ago and he stated that where the parents insisted on such an action and continued to insist the Department did not insist on the regulation being carried out. Therefore you will see very clearly that I have good grounds for feeling that the present conditions are bound to work out in such a way as will be unfair to us and will give an undue advantage to the R.C. people. Let the Indian Department give me a sufficient guarantee that none of our pupils will be allowed to go into the St. Phillips School and I shall be satisfied. Otherwise I shall carry this matter to such authorities in our Church as will compel justice to be done. Surely this is only what is fair.

There are a number of children on this Reserve now who should go to school but are not going anywhere. I shall be pleased to hear from you further in regard to this matter.

(Sgd.) W. McWhinney.

Report on St. Philips Indian Residential School

I wish to inform you that during my last inspection trip to the Pelly Agency, just before Christmas, I visited the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

Buildings

As a Mr. Wallace, from Winnipeg, with whom I am not acquainted, inspected the buildings shortly before I arrived, there is no need for me to make any reference to them.

Farming

There is a farm operated in connection with the School consisting of 280 acres but only 90 acres of this is under cultivation. The crop harvested last Fall was only fair.

Cattle

The number of cattle kept at the School is 20 and 9 of these animals are cows. The Principal informed me that naturally the 9 cows did not furnish sufficient milk for the School as there are times during the year when some of these cows are dry and to keep more cows at the School it would be necessary to build an addition on the barn, which is a good building but not long enough to take care of more cattle than are being housed at the present time. However, I notice that the School has built a stable out of logs and they house some of the younger stock there. They have 7 horses, 2 of which are old, and they also keep pigs and chickens.

Health

There are 76 children in residence at the School and this is two more than the grant of 74. I spoke to these children in their classrooms and playrooms and they all looked well and happy. From all appearances this School is run very well and I believe we have a first class Principal in Father Paradis.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON PELLY INDIAN AGENCY

SCHOOLS

We only have one Residential school situated in this agency, but they have been fortunate in being able to keep a capable staff of teachers all during the war, and children attending are much further advanced than those attending the day schools, and are also obtaining other useful instruction, in house work, cooking, sewing, carpenter work, painting, and care of stock, and are certainly much better fitted for a useful life upon leaving school. About the only complaint from the Indians that you hear about this school is that too much time is devoted to religious training. It would be a great help to many of the girls if they were allowed to continue their studies until they were at least 17 years of age, they would thus avoid some of the pitfalls that face them as they leave school at sixteen. Unfortunately in many cases they get little help or encouragement to conduct themselves properly, and parents appear to have very little control over them, and in many cases the example of the parents leaves a great deal to be desired.

Indian Agent.

I saw Mr. J. Bryant this morning about this question, and his answer was that the children were not in school, and that he saw no other alternative than they remain in school. They are in here by the will of the parents who do not want to see their children going to a far-away school. And the fact is that all other schools have also more children than they should, so they can not take the ones we have to many.

And as said Mr. Bryant, we are not to put these children in the road, they again school to stay, we have made room for them. We have exchange some large beds for smaller ones. A six foot bed is too large for a child of 7 or 8 or 9 years of age. So with smaller beds, we were able to put more in the same room.

In your letter you give an number of beds 75. We have now 81, that means only five more. As for the air space we can provide good air by more ventilation.

As Mr. Bryant was saying this morning, you have gone out of your way to accommodate these children it is but fair and just that you be paid for their upkeep.

These children have just as much right to school as any other child. And if we have to send them back home, it would be fair to them.

If our school is too small, this is not our fault. Here is the whole trouble. This school is too small all together. We had to refuse many children this year, so many children are without schooling, although it was promised to the Indians that schools would be given them and the facilities to acquire an education.

You have handled school affairs long enough to know how hard it is for a small school, to make both ends meet. I have here as many employees as in any other schools. It cost me just as much for fuel, light, water etc., as in most schools. And because these schools are paid for 100 to 120 they will receive nearly up to $1,000 every three months, whilst I receive $150.00. And these schools complain that it is hard for them to make both ends meet, what about us then?

So I sincerely hope that you will reconsider this question and that soon you may let me know that I will be paid for children present in school. I am not asking for a favour, but that justice be given to this school as to other schools.

I remain,

Sincerely Yours,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st 1945.

Education

Indian education is a subject that has, I am sure given our department and all who are really interested in the Indians, very serious thought, the problems are many and it would appear that there is still room for some improvement in our present set up. Very few of the day schools have qualified teachers and I think these should be employed by the department and not by any church organization if we are going to get suitable men and women for this very important work. A day school teacher could be employed for the full 12 months, and they should devote considerable in organizing sports and healthy recreation for the young people.

We have one Residential school and two day schools at this agency, but have several pupils from all reserves attending residential schools at other points in Saskatchewan and Manitoba. In a residential school good management and an efficient teaching staff are a prime necessity and in St Philips school here, we fortunately have a good teaching staff and a school that is exceptionally well managed. Apart from academic subjects the pupils are taught cooking, sewing, general housework, manual training, field work, care of livestock, and poultry etc. This school is filled to capacity at present and there are several pupils at home at present that should be in school if accommodation was available. There should be provision made for at least another 40 pupils and this may not be sufficient in another ten years. We would also like to see pupils that are anxious to make something of themselves, given the opportunity of staying on in school after they are 15 years old, in fact I think it would be a great help to many of the girls if they were kept in Boarding school at least another year longer.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.
I beg to submit herewith a report on the affairs of this Agency, for the quarter ending June 30th, 1946.

EDUCATION:

Miss Robertson of Cot Bay school has returned to her home and I understand will not return. She is a very fine woman and certainly did not spare herself trying to manage a very heavy school. However she has been in poor health and latterly the children became very difficult for her to handle, infact they were almost out of hand entirely. In the appointment of a successor I think we should insist on a male teacher, as I do not think there would be a bit of use sending another woman teacher for this difficult school. There is also to be a change at Key Day school, and here again I hope we can have someone appointed that really knows something about teaching and the handling of Indian children. Nothing definite has been done about starting day school at Valley River. We may have to use some of the new catholic church for this purpose until we can build a school at a rental of $40.00 per month, but here again I would not recommend starting a day school there unless we can be assured that a male teacher that has some experience can be supplied for that point.

St Philips Residential school has built an addition to the present school and will be able to accommodate more pupils this coming term. This school is well managed, children are happy and on the whole parents are satisfied with the results.

J.L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 18th, in which you renew your request for an increased pupilage at the St. Philips Indian Residential School.

I have been informed by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch that somewhat similar requests have been received by them from the Cariboo, Kamloops, Lejac, Sechelt and Squamish Residential Schools, amounting, if granted, to an additional enrolment at these schools of one hundred and seven pupils.

The Minister, to whom this request was submitted, naturally hesitated to grant it at this particular time for a number of reasons. The educational policy of the Indian Affairs Branch is, as you know, under review by a Special Parliamentary Committee, the members of which will no doubt make definite recommendations with respect to the educational needs of the Indian population in due course. In addition to this, it is our intention to have a number of educational surveys undertaken by a capable educationist at the earliest possible date. These surveys will be designed to determine the educational needs of Indians over a long period of years and to determine also how these needs can be most effectively met, particularly by the establishment of improved Indian day schools. It would not, in our judgment, be fair to the Churches to grant increased enrolments at this date, only to discover later that the operation of day schools was seriously reducing the number of pupils seeking residential school accommodation. This is a matter on which the Churches cooperating with the Government in the operation of schools will no doubt desire to make certain recommendations; in the meantime and until such recommendations are made, we feel that it would be in the interests of all parties concerned to continue the operation of our schools with the enrolments already authorized.
