Dear Mr. Jackson,

I beg to acknowledge yours of September 27th last written in answer to my request for an increase of pupilage at the St. Philips Indian Residential School. You also mention in your letter, a request of a similar nature which I made for the British Columbia Catholic Residential School.

I am very much surprised at the stand taken by yourself and your Minister in this very serious matter. All the schools for which an increase has been asked are situated in districts where a large proportion of the Indians are growing up in ignorance. Our Church is acquainted with this fact and is doing everything possible to supply education to as large a number of children as it is humanly possible to do so; but the cooperation of your Department is essential to enable them to continue this policy.

We know that it is the intention of your Department to have educational surveys made throughout the Dominion. We approve of these surveys, but as Government Agencies move slowly, a whole generation of Indian children is likely to grow up in ignorance, waiting for their results. This is most unfortunate and should not exist. You know, for instance, that Bishop Couët has been asking for a much needed residential school in his Vicariate and that your Department has been delaying the execution of this project with the statement that an educational survey would be made. Nothing has yet been done and in the meantime, the Bishop has had to send over forty Catholic children to schools, a thousand miles away.

Furthermore, we are not asking for these increases as a permanent policy of the Department. We are willing to take these children presently in our residential schools, on the understanding that if later on, any survey made by your Department should find it necessary to reduce the pupilage of these schools on account of the establishment of day schools in the same territory, we will gladly return to our former pupilage. What is uppermost in our mind at the present moment is that these Indian children are growing up in ignorance and something should be done, not in three or four or five years, but immediately, to relieve the situation.

PP/MGD
Kamsack, Sask.,
July 9th, 1947.

Education,

St Phillips Residential School is well staffed and is well managed under Principal Rev. Fr. Tetrault, however they have had considerable trouble the past year with a few of the larger girls and in many cases did not get any co-operation from the parents.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, October 8, 1947.

Dear Father Plourde:

We have just received the September quarter return from the St. Phillip's Residential School and it is signed by Rev. A. Ruest, Principal.

We have no official communication to the effect that he has been appointed principal in succession to Father Tetrault.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD
Ottawa, October 9, 1947.

Father Flourde advises of the following changes in Principals under date of October 9th. Original on file 121-5-1.

Reverend Father V. de Varennes, O.M.I., now Principal of the Muscowequan Indian Residential School, to become Principal of the Fort Frances School, Ontario.

Reverend Father Omer Robideux, O.M.I., who has been acting as Assistant Principal in the Muscowequan school, to become its Principal.

Reverend Father A. Ruest, O.M.I., who has been acting for the last two years as Assistant Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, to become Principal of the St. Philippe School, Saskatchewan.
In reference to the above, please be advised that in p.m. of this date Father HUST of the St. Phillips Indian School, called at this office and stated that the optionally noted was missing from the school and believed to have run away. He stated that they had missed her at about 10:30 a.m. same date as above. She was only 12 years of age and at the time of her disappearance, was dressed only in a night house dress. Father HUST was of the opinion that she may be trying to go back to LeBreton, Sask., where she used to go to school or back to her home at Carlisle. He stated that he would like police assistance and if located to make arrangements for her transportation back to the Indian School.

A check was made around town by Sgt. Forbes and the writer as to the possibility of the girl having come to Kamsack. This failed to produce results, so a patrol was made to the outskirts of town on Highway towards St. Phillips. In a short while an Indian girl was sighted in the ditch walking towards Kamsack. When questioned, she stated that she was Norma WHITEHORSE from the St. Phillips School and was running away because she did not like the place.

A patrol was made by Sgt. Forbes and the writer to the St. Phillips Indian School, where the girl was handed over to Father JANGOTE. Patrol returned to detachment at 6:00 p.m. same date. This file is considered closed at this detachment.
